This is a high-risk scenario for the Council – either it gets its plan back on track (perhaps by scaling back or firming up the evidence for its allocations and getting it adopted in 2024/25), or it faces potentially losing control of where and how Green Belt is breached. In the interim, South Staffs has leaned on temporary measures like a 2020 Memorandum of Understanding with the West Midlands on housing apportionment, but that’s tenuous after the Black Country plan collapse. Until the Local Plan is resolved, the district’s development management is precariously balanced between unmet needs and Green Belt protection, making it one of the more vulnerable planning situations currently.

name: South Somerset District Council (now Somerset)
notes_short: South Somerset’s Local Plan (2015) is out-of-date and was due for review by 2020, but the process halted as the district merged into Somerset Council in 2023. Yeovil and market towns have seen growth from the 2015 plan, but key sites (like the urban extension) lagged, causing some housing shortfall. Until Somerset’s new unitary plan addresses this, South Somerset relies on the old policies and often the NPPF presumption to decide applications.
notes: The South Somerset Local Plan 2006-2028 was adopted in March 2015 after a partial withdrawal and re-examination (the Yeovil Sustainable Urban Extension was re-evaluated at that time). It set a strategy focusing major growth at Yeovil (including an urban extension of around 1,500 homes), and significant allocations at market towns like Chard, Wincanton, and Crewkerne. While many housing sites in Yeovil and other towns have been built, some strategic projects (Chard’s urban extension with relief road, and the Yeovil extension) have progressed slowly or stalled. By the late 2010s, South Somerset struggled to maintain a five-year supply, dipping to about 4 years at worst, which triggered the tilted balance in a number of appeal decisions. The Council had begun a Local Plan Review with Issues consultation in 2020 to plan to 2040, but with local government reorganization, that work ceased and will fold into the new Somerset-wide plan eventually. Now under Somerset Council, the South Somerset area still uses the 2015 plan policies – which are outdated, especially on housing numbers (based on old targets). Consequently, decisions in 2023-2024 have often had to lean on NPPF para.11(d). For instance, some speculative proposals on Yeovil’s edge or in rural settlements have been allowed to make up for the lagging strategic sites. The risk here is relatively high until a new plan allocates alternative or additional sites to meet the shortfall. However, the recent uptick in housing delivery (South Somerset approved many homes in the past couple of years to address the deficit) means the five-year supply is improving, which should help mitigate presumption issues in the short term. Still, without an updated plan beyond 2028, the area lacks a forward strategy for growth, affordable housing, and infrastructure planning (especially important as Yeovil’s economy diversifies post-AgustaWestland). The forthcoming Somerset Council Local Plan will need to identify new solutions – possibly a new settlement along the A303 corridor or bolstering growth at stronger market towns – to pick up where the 2015 plan leaves off. Until then, South Somerset remains vulnerable to ad hoc development driven by the absence of an up-to-date local framework.

name: South Ribble Borough Council
notes_short: South Ribble’s strategic planning is via the 2012 Central Lancashire Core Strategy (and a 2015 Sites DPD). These are now old, though a Memorandum of Understanding on housing supply between Preston, South Ribble, and Chorley has helped manage tilted balance issues. A new Central Lancs Local Plan is in advanced drafting (Publication Feb 2025), which will replace the 2012 strategy by 2025. The current framework, while dated, has largely held thanks to inter-authority coordination.
notes: South Ribble shares the **Central Lancashire Core Strategy 2012 with Preston and Chorley, and has its own Local Plan (Sites & Development Management) adopted in 2015. Together, these guided significant growth in South Ribble, notably the Buckshaw Village new town (joint with Chorley) and major employment expansion at Cuerden (Lancashire Central). By late 2010s, housing delivery across Central Lancs was running ahead of plan, leading to debates on whether the Core Strategy’s housing requirement was still applicable. To avoid speculative appeals exploiting “outdated” figures, the Central Lancs authorities agreed a Memorandum of Understanding in 2020 to use increased housing targets and apportion them – effectively staving off the tilted balance argument successfully in recent appeals. South Ribble has consistently maintained over 5 years supply under these higher numbers. Meanwhile, the councils have been working on a new Central Lancashire Local Plan (2023-2038), with a Publication Draft issued in Feb 2025 (for submission later in 2025). For South Ribble, the new plan will allocate further growth likely around Penwortham and Leyland (building on the success of Buckshaw and new infrastructure like the Penwortham bypass), and refresh employment land supply to capitalize on the Preston City Deal. Until this new plan is adopted (expected by 2025/26), South Ribble’s development management relies on the 2012/2015 plans plus the agreed interim housing requirement approach. This has so far prevented major unplanned developments – most applications are coming on allocated or brownfield urban sites. The risk of plan-led control loss is moderate: if the new plan were significantly delayed or one of the partner councils diverged from the MoU, tilted balance issues could re-emerge. However, the joint working has been strong and is on track to deliver the updated plan. In essence, while South Ribble’s formal plan is “old,” proactive cooperation and buffer in land supply have kept speculative development at bay, and with a new local plan imminent, the borough’s planning risk is being managed effectively.

name: South Oxfordshire District Council
notes_short: South Oxfordshire’s Local Plan was adopted in Dec 2020 under a government direction and is up-to-date, providing for large developments (Chalgrove, Didcot Garden Town). It runs to 2035. The district is now working jointly with Vale of White Horse on a new combined plan to 2041, submitted in Dec 2024. The current plan remains effective in guiding growth, so risk of unplanned development is low.
notes: After a controversial process, South Oxfordshire’s Local Plan 2011-2035 was adopted in December 2020. It allocates significant housing growth, including a strategic new community at Chalgrove Airfield (3,000 homes, though this has faced delivery uncertainties due to Ministry of Defence land issues) and major expansions at Didcot (Garden Town) and around Thame and Wallingford. The plan was imposed with high housing targets to assist Oxford City’s unmet need (South Oxon agreed to take ~4,000 of Oxford’s overflow). With adoption, the plan is up-to-date and the Council has been granting permissions accordingly – Didcot’s Valley Park and Culham sites are moving ahead, for example. The district currently can demonstrate a five-year supply, bolstered by these strategic sites in the pipeline (though Chalgrove’s timing is still in question, alternative sites can backfill if needed). To look beyond 2035 and cement cooperation, South Oxfordshire is now preparing a Joint Local Plan 2041 with Vale of White Horse District; that joint plan was submitted for examination in Dec 2024. Until the new joint plan is adopted (likely 2025/26), the 2020 plan continues to apply and is largely sufficient. There have been few successful speculative proposals since adoption – developers know large commitments are already in place and the Council can robustly refuse departures (backed by the SoS’s firm stance in getting this plan through). The main risk factor is if any big allocation falters (e.g., if Chalgrove ultimately cannot proceed, the council might lack a portion of supply in the late 2020s). However, the emerging joint plan is poised to adjust for that by possibly identifying contingency growth areas. In summary, the present Local Plan gives South Oxfordshire a strong grip on development – the tilted balance is not currently in play – and with the proactive step of a joint plan underway, the district’s planning framework is in a good position, minimizing risk of unwanted speculative development.

name: South Norfolk District Council
notes_short: South Norfolk, as part of Greater Norwich, has an up-to-date Local Plan. The Greater Norwich Joint Core Strategy was supplemented by the new Greater Norwich Local Plan (GNLP) adopted in early 2022, allocating growth to 2038. South Norfolk also has a separate Village Clusters plan in progress. The planning framework is sound, with ample housing sites (including the new settlement at Hethel) identified, so speculative development risk is low.
notes: South Norfolk’s strategic planning is now covered by the Greater Norwich Local Plan 2018–2038, which was adopted in January 2022 (except for one deferred site). This joint plan with Broadland and Norwich updated the earlier Joint Core Strategy (2011). For South Norfolk, it means allocations for major growth around the Norwich fringe (e.g., at Cringleford, Hethersett), expansion of market towns like Wymondham and Long Stratton (where a bypass is planned alongside housing), and a new settlement at Hethel later in the plan period. Additionally, South Norfolk is finalizing a separate Village Clusters plan (to manage small-scale housing in rural villages) due in 2024. With this comprehensive framework, South Norfolk has an up-to-date plan and a healthy land supply; it can comfortably demonstrate more than five years’ worth of deliverable sites, given the many allocations and broad distribution of growth. The Council is therefore well-armed to resist proposals contrary to the plan – indeed, appeals for unplanned large sites have dropped post-GNLP adoption. The tilted balance isn’t engaged, since housing delivery in Greater Norwich has been meeting targets. As of now, no immediate plan review is required (the GNLP will be reviewed by 2027 per policy but likely only minor tweaks). The only slight risk factor is ensuring infrastructure keeps pace (the Long Stratton bypass is key to unlocking allocated homes there – any delay could bottleneck those allocations, but contingency sites exist elsewhere if needed). Overall, South Norfolk’s planning regime is robust: the area’s growth is being channeled through an up-to-date joint strategy, leaving little room or incentive for speculative development.

name: South Lakeland District Council (now Westmorland & Furness)
notes_short: South Lakeland’s planning documents (Core Strategy 2010, Land Allocations 2013) are outdated. A Local Plan review began but was overtaken by local government reorg: in 2023 South Lakeland merged into Westmorland & Furness Council. Its areas (Kendal, Ulverston, etc.) now await the new Westmorland & Furness Local Plan due by 2026. Until then, development in these areas relies on old policies and the NPPF, with modest growth continuing but some policy gaps (e.g., limited provision for newer housing needs) evident.
notes: The former South Lakeland District’s Core Strategy was adopted in 2010 and its Land Allocations in 2013. These provided for growth mainly in Kendal and Ulverston up to 2025. By 2022, South Lakeland District Council had started reviewing its plan (Issues & Options consulted) to extend to 2040, but the process paused due to the abolition of the district in 2023. Now, planning for Kendal, Ulverston, and surrounding villages falls to Westmorland & Furness Council, which will create a new unitary-wide plan (as noted, likely by 2026). In the interim, the 2010/2013 policies remain in effect. They are clearly out-of-date – for instance, housing targets were low (based on an era of constrained assumptions) and many allocated sites are built or have permission. That said, the area’s development pressure is moderate (South Lakeland’s population is relatively stable, and part of the district lies in the Lake District National Park which has its own plan). Kendal and Ulverston have seen ongoing housing development on allocated and windfall sites, sufficient so far to generally maintain a five-year supply. There have been a few instances where developers pushed for unallocated edge-of-town sites citing the aged plan, but the Council (now Westmorland & Furness) has managed to defer major decisions pending the new plan, without a flood of appeals – partly because market demand is not as intense as in commuter belts elsewhere. The main risk is that certain needs (like affordable housing for local young people or specific employment land for new industries) aren’t being fully met under the old plan’s framework. The NPPF’s tilted balance could come into play if supply slips; careful monitoring is needed. Westmorland & Furness Council will likely incorporate much of the work done by South Lakeland into its new plan (ensuring Kendal’s future expansion or Ulverston’s infrastructure are addressed coherently). In summary, while the plan for this area is outdated, the relatively modest development environment has prevented serious unmanaged growth so far. However, a modern plan is needed soon to give clarity, especially as economic initiatives (like the Britain’s Energy Coast or increased tourism) could spark development interest that the old plan wasn’t designed to handle.

name: South Kesteven District Council
notes_short: South Kesteven’s Local Plan was adopted in January 2020 (covering 2011–2036) and is up-to-date. It allocates major growth to Grantham and new garden villages. A review is underway (Reg 18 consulted in 2022) to extend to 2041, but the current plan is sufficient to direct development and maintain supply in the interim.
notes: The South Kesteven Local Plan 2011-2036 was adopted in January 2020. It sets out significant development, notably a Garden Village at Spitalgate Heath, Grantham, urban extensions in Stamford and Bourne, and substantial housing in the market town of Grantham to support its growth as a sub-regional centre. Since adoption, the district has made progress: Grantham’s Southern Relief Road is under construction (facilitating the Spitalgate development), and housing delivery has been robust, exceeding targets. The plan is current, and the Council has a comfortable five-year land supply. Nevertheless, by policy, a review was to be considered within 5 years – the Council initiated that process with Issues & Options consultation in late 2022. The review (to plan to 2041) will consider if further sites are needed (possibly expanding the new village at Spitalgate or another at Barrowby) and update policies on climate change and design. However, progress of the review has been measured, partly due to awaiting the outcome of national planning reforms. In the meantime, the 2020 plan is solidly in force. Developers are largely focusing on the allocated sites (demand is strong in this area, including commuter demand for Peterborough and London via the A1/ECML). With supply ample, the tilted balance hasn’t been invoked in recent decisions – appeals have mostly been dismissed if not in line with the plan’s spatial strategy. One area of note: Stamford’s growth is somewhat constrained by cross-boundary issues with Rutland (which withdrew its plan in 2021), but South Kesteven’s plan has contingencies to accommodate needed growth if Rutland doesn’t. This has been managed via a Duty-to-Cooperate addendum rather than needing to re-open the plan. In summary, South Kesteven faces low planning risk: an up-to-date plan underpins decision-making, speculative development is minimal, and the Council is proactively working on a next plan to avoid any future gaps – all of which keeps development plan-led and in line with local objectives.

name: Exeter LPA
notes_short: Core Strategy adopted Feb 2012 is out-of-date; Exeter is working on a new Local Plan (the ‘Exeter Plan’ to 2040) with a full draft published Dec 2024 but not yet adopted.
notes: Exeter’s current development plan is based on the Core Strategy adopted in February 2012 (which guided growth to 2026) and an older 2005 Local Plan for detailed policies. These documents are now quite old. The Core Strategy is 13 years since adoption, meaning its housing targets and policies are out-of-date relative to Exeter’s rapidly evolving needs. The city has been in the process of creating a new local plan, known as the “Exeter Plan,” to look ahead to 2040. A Draft Exeter Plan was published for consultation in late 2022, and by December 2024 the City Council released the Full Publication draft for the next stage of consultation. This new plan aims to allocate enough sites to accommodate around 13,500 homes by 2040, focusing on urban brownfield development and some urban extensions, in line with Exeter’s goal of sustainable growth. The Exeter Plan is expected to be submitted for examination in 2025. In the interim, because Exeter’s existing plan is out-of-date, the council must rely on the NPPF and the regional Spatial Strategy (Devon’s housing frameworks) to judge proposals. Exeter is somewhat shielded by geography – as a compact city with finite land, there have been fewer greenfield speculative applications than in more rural districts. Nonetheless, without an up-to-date plan, the council faces challenges in resisting proposals that fall outside its old policies, especially if it cannot demonstrate a five-year housing land supply. The risk will persist until the new local plan is adopted (likely by 2026). Once the Exeter Plan is in place, it will modernize the policy context, incorporate the city’s climate ambitions, and greatly reduce the current uncertainty in development management.
references: Exeter’s Core Strategy was adopted in Feb 2012
Exeter has a new Local Plan in preparation (the Exeter Plan to 2040); a full draft was published in Dec 2024 and is expected to be submitted for examination in 2025.

name: Erewash LPA
notes_short: Core Strategy adopted March 2014 is under a formal Review. A revised Core Strategy (Part 1 Local Plan) was submitted in 2022 and is nearing adoption, which will update Erewash’s policies.
notes: Erewash’s current adopted plan is the Core Strategy (Part 1 Local Plan) for Greater Nottingham, which was adopted in March 2014. This joint Core Strategy (with Broxtowe, Nottingham City, and Gedling) provides strategic policies through 2028. Given its age (11 years old), Erewash’s plan required review. The Borough Council has pursued a Core Strategy Review, which it submitted for independent examination on 30 November 2022. Examination hearings took place in mid-2024, and by September 2024 the Inspector issued a post-hearings letter indicating what modifications were needed. The review process has involved proposing updates to housing numbers and adjustments to allocations to extend the plan horizon to 2041 (renamed the Erewash Core Strategy Review 2020). As of early 2025, the Inspector’s final report is anticipated, and adoption of the reviewed plan is likely in 2025. During this transition, the 2014 Core Strategy remains the operative plan. Because it’s more than 5 years old, the NPPF’s tilted balance is engaged for housing applications, but the fact that a replacement plan is imminent gives the Council stronger grounds to resist proposals that conflict with the soon-to-be-adopted strategy. In effect, Erewash is in limbo for a short period: policy weight is somewhat diminished until the new plan is adopted. The risk of speculative development existed in the early 2020s when the plan became dated, but now with the Review at an advanced stage, that risk is moderating. Once the Erewash Core Strategy Review is adopted (with updated targets to 2037 or 2041), the borough will again have an up-to-date framework, closing the current policy gap.
references: Erewash’s current Core Strategy was adopted in March 2014.
The Erewash Core Strategy Review (2020) has been submitted as of Nov 2022 and underwent hearings in 2024, moving the plan toward adoption.

name: Epsom and Ewell LPA
plan_status: Core Strategy from 2007 (New plan submitted March 2025)
notes_short: Core Strategy from 2007 is highly out-of-date, but a new Local Plan 2022–2040 was submitted in March 2025 and is headed for examination.
notes: Epsom & Ewell’s planning policy has been outdated for many years, as the borough’s current Core Strategy dates back to July 2007. That Core Strategy (intended to run to 2022) and a small number of later Development Management policies are still the statutory development plan. This policy vacuum has made it difficult for the council to resist speculative development, since by NPPF definition the policies are out-of-date and housing need defaults to the standard method. Recognizing this, Epsom & Ewell Borough Council has worked on a new Local Plan to address modern requirements. The new Local Plan 2022–2040 has now reached an advanced stage: a Regulation 19 Pre-Submission consultation took place over winter 2024/25, and the plan was officially submitted to the Secretary of State on 10 March 2025. An Inspector will be appointed and examination hearings are expected later in 2025. The submitted plan aims to significantly boost housing delivery (it proposes to meet a target of around 540 homes per year, including some Green Belt releases, to achieve ~10,000 new homes by 2040). While this new plan is under examination, decision-making in Epsom must still rely on the 2007/Core Strategy policies, which carry very limited weight. The tilted balance firmly applies, and indeed Epsom has seen many developments come forward in recent years that bypass local zoning due to the lack of up-to-date plan. The council’s hope is that the new Local Plan will be found sound and adopted by mid-2026, finally replacing the antiquated policies and regaining control over development. Until then, Epsom remains at high risk of unplanned projects, but the imminent prospect of an adopted plan suggests this situation could improve in the near future.
references: Epsom & Ewell’s current Core Strategy was adopted in July 2007 and is one of the oldest local plans still in effect, well beyond the 5-year review period.
The Borough Council submitted a new Local Plan 2022–2040 for examination in March 2025, aiming to replace the outdated 2007 plan once it is adopted.

name: Epping Forest LPA
notes_short: New Local Plan 2011–2033 adopted in March 2023 after a protracted examination; policies are up-to-date and development is guided by this plan.
notes: Epping Forest District finally achieved an up-to-date local plan in 2023. The Epping Forest District Local Plan 2011–2033 was adopted on 6 March 2023. This marked the end of a lengthy examination process that began with submission back in 2017. The delay was largely due to concerns about environmental impacts on Epping Forest Special Area of Conservation and other issues, which required extensive modifications and mitigation strategies. The adopted plan allocates significant new housing (around 11,400 homes) across the district to meet needs to 2033 and includes policies addressing those environmental constraints. Because the plan is less than five years old, Epping Forest can robustly defend planning decisions using its new policies. The council currently has a 5-year housing land supply identified in the plan, and per NPPF paragraph 75, it is exempt from needing to continually demonstrate supply until the plan is five years old. This means speculative development proposals that conflict with the plan can be refused with confidence that the presumption in favor does not override the plan. Epping Forest’s situation has thus improved dramatically since early 2023 – previously it lacked an adopted plan, but now the risk of unplanned development is low. Going forward, the council will need to commence a review by 2028, but in the near term the focus will be on delivering the allocations and infrastructure set out in the newly adopted plan.
references: Epping Forest District Council adopted its Local Plan (2011–2033) in March 2023.
Because the plan is <5 years old and had a confirmed 5-year housing supply on adoption, NPPF paragraph 77’s provisions mean the tilted balance is not engaged.

name: Enfield LPA
plan_status: Core Strategy adopted 2010 (New plan in Examination)
notes_short: Core Strategy adopted 2010 is out-of-date, but a new Enfield Local Plan (to 2041) is currently at Examination, aiming to replace the old policies soon.
notes: Enfield’s current Local Plan consists of a Core Strategy adopted in November 2010 and a Development Management Document from 2014. These are significantly out-of-date with respect to current London Plan targets and national policy. Recognizing this, Enfield Council has drafted a new Local Plan extending to 2041. The draft plan was submitted for examination in 2023, and the Examination in Public began with Stage 1 hearings in January 2025. The emerging plan is ambitious, proposing to meet a high housing need partly by allocating Green Belt land for development (approximately 9,000 homes on two large Green Belt sites). This has been controversial but also elicited support from the Mayor of London, who acknowledged that some Green Belt release in Enfield is “unavoidable” to meet housing demand. As the examination continues in 2025, Enfield hopes to adopt the new plan by 2025/26. In the meantime, because the 2010 Core Strategy is over 5 years old, Enfield’s housing decisions must apply the NPPF tilted balance. The borough has a substantial housing shortfall under the national standard method, and without an updated plan it has struggled to demonstrate a five-year supply. This has left Enfield vulnerable to developers—indeed, some larger schemes have come forward anticipating the new plan’s policies or exploiting the current policy gap. The plan’s advanced stage offers light at the end of the tunnel: if the Enfield Local Plan 2041 is adopted in the next year or so, it will restore a sound policy framework and significantly reduce the risk of unplanned development. Until then, Enfield’s planning authority navigates a delicate period with an aging plan but a replacement in progress, balancing development pressures against interim London Plan targets and emerging local policies.
references: Enfield’s Core Strategy was adopted in Nov 2010 and covers development to 2025. It is now over 15 years old.
The new Enfield Local Plan (2023 draft, covering to 2041) entered its examination hearings in Jan 2025, with proposals including significant Green Belt housing allocations.

name: Elmbridge LPA
notes_short: Core Strategy from 2011 remains in force after a new draft Local Plan was withdrawn in 2024–25, leaving Elmbridge without an up-to-date plan and under intense development pressure.
notes: Elmbridge’s planning policy is severely out-of-date. The current Core Strategy was adopted in July 2011, and no comprehensive update has been successful since then. The Borough Council worked for many years on a new Local Plan and submitted a draft plan for examination in August 2023. However, the Planning Inspector examining it found the plan unsound in September 2024, principally because it significantly undershot the required housing need and proposed no Green Belt release. The Inspector indicated the plan could only be made sound with major modifications (increasing housing provision). Faced with this, Elmbridge requested an extension of time to rework the plan, which the government refused. Consequently, in February 2025 the council withdrew the draft plan to start over. As of 2025, Elmbridge has returned to the drawing board, and adoption of a new plan is unlikely before 2028. In the interim, the 2011 Core Strategy (and a 2015 Development Management plan) are the only adopted policies, all of which predate the current NPPF. This means virtually all development applications will be considered under the tilted balance – Elmbridge cannot demonstrate a five-year housing supply or an up-to-date plan. The borough is already experiencing speculative applications on Green Belt and other sensitive sites, which the Council may struggle to refuse on policy grounds. Until a new plan is adopted, Elmbridge’s planning control is limited. The risk of unplanned developments being allowed on appeal is extremely high given the policy vacuum. The situation underscores an acute need for a new sound local plan, as well as potential intervention (the area’s unmet housing need is also part of wider sub-regional discussions). Overall, Elmbridge’s plan status represents one of the highest-risk scenarios in the country at present.
references: Elmbridge’s Core Strategy (the current local plan) was adopted in July 2011 and is one of the oldest in England.
The draft Elmbridge Local Plan 2023 was deemed unsound by the Inspector for failing to meet housing needs (refusing to release Green Belt), leading the Council to withdraw it in early 2025.

name: Eden District Council (now Westmorland & Furness)
notes_short: Local Plan 2014–2032 was adopted in October 2018; now over 5 years old and due for review, but restructuring of councils has delayed an update.
notes: The Eden Local Plan 2014–2032 was adopted on 11 October 2018. It covers the former Eden District’s development needs (housing, employment, etc.) up to 2032. By 2025, this plan is about 7 years old, meaning it is outside the ideal 5-year currency period. A review was initiated by Eden District Council’s executive in 2019 to assess necessary updates, but progress was overtaken by local government reorganisation. In April 2023, Eden District was merged into the new Westmorland and Furness unitary authority. The new council will need to produce a unified local plan for its area, incorporating Eden, but this process is in its early stages. As a result, Eden’s 2018 Local Plan remains the operative plan for its area, and its policies (while relatively recent) are technically out-of-date under the NPPF’s 5-year rule. The degree of risk is moderate: Eden has generally met its modest housing targets, but moving forward, the standard method will dictate housing need until a new plan is in place. The rural nature of the district and the fact that the plan runs to 2032 mean the existing allocations still guide current development, reducing immediate pressure. However, without a timely update, Eden (now Westmorland and Furness for planning purposes) could see developers arguing the tilted balance for additional sites. The transition to the new unitary plan adds uncertainty in timing. In summary, Eden’s plan is out-of-date and awaiting a comprehensive review under the new authority, creating a pause in up-to-date plan-making and some vulnerability until an updated plan is adopted.
references: The Eden Local Plan 2014–2032 was adopted on 11 October 2018 (by the former Eden District Council) and is now over 5 years old.
Eden’s plan review has been absorbed into the new Westmorland and Furness Council’s plan-making, following local government reorganisation in 2023.

name: Eastleigh LPA
notes_short: Local Plan 2016–2036 was adopted in April 2022, so the borough has an up-to-date plan and is now beginning an early review.
notes: Eastleigh succeeded in adopting a long-delayed Local Plan in April 2022, covering the period 2016–2036. This plan provides for 14,580 new homes and associated infrastructure by 2036. Because it was adopted less than five years ago, all its policies are currently considered up-to-date under the NPPF. The council can demonstrate a five-year housing land supply based on this recently adopted plan, meaning the tilted balance is not engaged. Having an adopted 2022 plan greatly reduces Eastleigh’s risk of speculative development — planning applications are determined in accordance with the up-to-date allocations and policies. However, the plan did have a notable housing shortfall (around 2,600 homes not allocated) even at adoption, which the council acknowledges will need to be addressed. Eastleigh has already begun initial work on a potential Local Plan review to extend the plan period and meet longer-term needs, though this is at a very early stage. In summary, Eastleigh’s planning status is secure in the short term due to its newly adopted plan. Any development risks are low, primarily centering on the need to plan for growth beyond 2036. The council’s focus will be on monitoring delivery and starting the next plan update before any policy lapse occurs.
references: Eastleigh’s Local Plan 2016–2036 was found sound in March 2022 and formally adopted in April 2022.

The current plan meets most needs to 2036, though it includes a housing shortfall to be addressed (14,580 homes planned vs. higher assessed need), prompting the Council to consider options for a future review.

name: Eastbourne LPA
notes_short: Core Strategy adopted in Feb 2013 is substantially out-of-date; a new Local Plan 2019–2039 is being prepared but not yet in force.
notes: Eastbourne’s current adopted plan is the Core Strategy Local Plan 2006–2027, which was adopted in February 2013. That plan is now 12 years old and its horizon year (2027) is approaching. The South Downs National Park Authority now handles planning for areas of Eastbourne within the National Park, but for the rest of the borough the 2013 Core Strategy remains the operative plan. Eastbourne Borough Council has been working on a replacement Local Plan (covering 2019–2039) for several years. A draft emerging plan was under consultation (initial Reg.18 stages were around 2019), but as of 2025 this new plan has not yet been submitted for examination. Thus, the borough is still relying on policies that predate the NPPF 2019/2021 revisions. This leaves Eastbourne in a vulnerable position regarding housing delivery: the adopted plan’s housing targets and allocations are dated, and under the NPPF the plan’s policies are considered out-of-date (triggering the tilted balance) due to age. The council will likely need to accelerate the new Local Plan 2019–2039 to regain control over development. In the meantime, development proposals may come forward on unallocated sites, citing the lack of an up-to-date plan. While Eastbourne is heavily constrained (bounded by the sea and national park), the absence of recent plan policies increases the risk of appeals and speculative projects. Completion and adoption of the new plan will be critical to guiding growth and resisting unwanted development.
references: Eastbourne’s Core Strategy was adopted in February 2013 and is the current development plan (for the area outside the National Park).
An emerging Eastbourne Local Plan 2019–2039 is in preparation, but until it is adopted the council’s policies (now 12 years old) carry reduced weight.

name: East Suffolk LPA
notes_short: Two Local Plans cover East Suffolk (Waveney adopted 2019, Suffolk Coastal 2020); the older Waveney plan just hit 5-year review and will be updated.
notes: East Suffolk was formed in 2019 and is covered by two local plans corresponding to the former districts. The Waveney Local Plan was adopted on 20 March 2019, and the Suffolk Coastal Local Plan was adopted in September 2020. As of 2025, the Waveney plan is just over 6 years old and the Suffolk Coastal plan about 4.5 years old. The council conducted a five-year review of the Waveney Plan in March 2024, which initially found the plan remained effective. However, a subsequent change (an updated NPPF with higher standard method housing figures) led East Suffolk to conclude that an update to the Waveney Local Plan is required. The Local Development Scheme (March 2024) sets an indicative timetable to begin this plan update. In practical terms, East Suffolk is in a relatively strong position short-term: both local plans are recently adopted, and the authority can demonstrate housing land supply under those plans. The Suffolk Coastal plan is still within five years of adoption (so its policies carry full weight), whereas the Waveney plan has just passed five years, meaning its housing policies will start to be considered “out-of-date” until updated. The council’s decision to update the Waveney plan (and likely to eventually unify the plans for the whole East Suffolk area) will address this. Overall, East Suffolk’s planning status is moderate risk – one plan remains up-to-date, and the other is undergoing an update process to ensure the whole district continues to have a robust policy framework.
references: East Suffolk’s area is covered by the Suffolk Coastal Local Plan (adopted Sept 2020) and the Waveney Local Plan (adopted 20 March 2019).
A March 2024 review concluded the Waveney Local Plan needs updating due to a significant uplift in housing need under the new NPPF standard method.

name: East Staffordshire LPA
notes_short: Local Plan adopted in October 2015 is now over 9 years old with no replacement yet adopted, increasing risk of speculative proposals.
notes: East Staffordshire’s Local Plan (2012–2031) was adopted on 15 October 2015. Now in 2025, it has been in place for a full decade. This means the plan’s strategic policies are more than five years old and in need of review to remain in line with the latest NPPF and housing requirements. The council has not adopted an updated plan since 2015, and there is little public evidence of a new local plan being at an advanced stage. By NPPF paragraph 75 and associated guidance, when a plan is over five years old the housing need is calculated using the standard method, which can significantly raise the borough’s housing target. East Staffordshire must therefore demonstrate a five-year housing land supply against potentially higher housing need figures or else the tilted balance will apply. The current situation puts the authority in a vulnerable position, as developers may pursue applications on less preferred sites, arguing the plan is out-of-date. In summary, East Staffordshire’s plan is overdue for replacement. Until a plan update is produced (the timing of which is uncertain), planning decisions will lean on an aging policy framework, and the council faces a high risk of planning by appeal under the presumption in favor of sustainable development.
references: East Staffordshire’s Local Plan was adopted in October 2015.
With the plan now over 5 years old, its policies are considered out-of-date under the NPPF, heightening the presumption in favor of sustainable development.

name: East Riding of Yorkshire LPA
notes_short: New Local Plan Update 2020–2039 was adopted in April 2025, replacing the previous 2016 Local Plan.
notes: East Riding has an up-to-date Local Plan. The council formally adopted the East Riding Local Plan Update (covering 2020–2039) on 2 April 2025. This new plan replaces the prior Local Plan (which was adopted in 2016 and ran to 2029). The Plan Update was found sound by an Inspector in December 2024 after extensive examination, including hearings in 2023 and modifications consultations. With the new plan now in force, East Riding benefits from an NPPF-compliant strategy with up-to-date allocations and policies on housing, employment, environment, etc. The tilted balance no longer applies, as the plan is less than five years old and contains an identified five-year housing land supply. This greatly reduces the risk of speculative or unplanned developments. In short, East Riding’s planning framework is current and robust following the 2025 adoption, providing certainty for development decisions and aligning local policy with national requirements.
references: East Riding Local Plan Update 2020–2039 was adopted by Full Council on 2 April 2025.
The new plan replaces the previous East Riding Local Plan (2012–2029) adopted in 2016, ensuring policies are up-to-date.

name: East Lindsey LPA
notes_short: Local Plan adopted July 2018 is under review; a Partial Review (2022–2041) is in examination to update the plan.
notes: East Lindsey’s current Local Plan (Core Strategy and Settlement allocations) was adopted on 18 July 2018. The plan covers development needs to 2031. Having exceeded five years since adoption, the council initiated a Local Plan Review to ensure it remains up-to-date. A Regulation 18 Issues & Options consultation took place in 2021/22, and subsequently the Council prepared a Partial Review of the plan. This Partial Review (covering the period 2022–2041) was submitted for examination in November 2022. Public hearings were held in mid-2024 as part of the examination process. As of early 2025, the Inspector has provided feedback and the council is working on modifications needed to find the plan sound. Until the Partial Review is adopted, East Lindsey relies on the 2018 plan. Because that plan is now over 5 years old, its housing policies are considered out-of-date by default, meaning the NPPF’s tilted balance can apply in decision-making. The ongoing review, once completed, will extend the plan’s horizon and update its policies (including potentially higher housing targets or new allocations). In the meantime, the district faces a moderate risk of speculative development, though the active progress on the plan update indicates the authority is addressing the issue. Full adoption of the reviewed Local Plan in 2025 will firm up the planning framework and reduce this risk.
references: East Lindsey Local Plan was adopted on 18 July 2018.
A Partial Review of the Local Plan (2022–2041) has been submitted and is under examination, following consultation in 2021/22.

name: East Hertfordshire LPA
notes_short: District Plan adopted October 2018 is just over 5 years old; review has commenced to update the plan.
notes: East Hertfordshire’s District Plan was adopted in October 2018, providing a development framework up to 2033. As of late 2023, this plan passed its five-year mark and is now subject to review. The council formally began a review in 2024, including a “Call for Sites” to inform a new plan iteration. The current adopted plan is only slightly older than five years, so it remains largely effective, but under the NPPF the housing requirements should now be considered against the government’s standard method (since the plan is over 5 years old). East Herts has successfully met recent housing targets (125% of requirement per the 2022 Housing Delivery Test), which may buffer it from immediate land supply shortages. However, without an update, policies will increasingly date relative to national policy changes. The council’s proactive move to launch a new plan process should limit the period of vulnerability. In summary, the 2018 District Plan is slightly out-of-date and will be updated through a new local plan process now underway. In the interim, the plan’s age means the tilted balance could apply for housing proposals, but the authority is actively working to refresh its policies.
references: East Herts District Plan was adopted on 23 October 2018, covering the period to 2033.
A five-year review began in 2024, with the Council inviting sites and evidence for a new plan.

name: East Hampshire LPA
notes_short: Core Strategy adopted 2014 (with allocations in 2016) is now out-of-date; a new draft Local Plan to 2040 is in preparation.
notes: East Hampshire’s current plan is composed of the Joint Core Strategy (adopted May 2014) and a Part 2 allocations plan (adopted April 2016). These documents are around 9–11 years old and cover the district (outside the South Downs National Park) up to 2028. The council has recognized that this framework is out-of-date. In late 2023, East Hampshire published a new draft Local Plan looking ahead to 2040. This emerging plan will replace the aging strategy and bring policies in line with current national requirements (e.g. on housing need and climate change). As of early 2025, the draft Plan has undergone committee consideration and public consultation, with submission and examination anticipated by 2025. Until the new plan is adopted, the district’s planning decisions must rely on the old policies, which triggers the NPPF tilted balance for housing proposals. East Hampshire has faced delay and uncertainty (its previous plan attempt was paused amid concerns). The risk of speculative development is relatively high in this gap period. Once the new Local Plan 2020–2040 is adopted, it should restore a firm policy basis, but currently the authority is in a transitional phase with an out-of-date plan under active replacement.
references: East Hampshire’s Joint Core Strategy was adopted in May 2014 (with Part 2 site allocations adopted April 2016).
A new draft Local Plan covering to 2040 was published at the end of 2023 and is proceeding toward consultation and examination.

name: East Devon LPA
notes_short: Local Plan (adopted 2016) is aging; a new Local Plan 2020–2040 is in final consultation before submission.
notes: East Devon’s currently adopted Local Plan (covering 2013–2031) was adopted in January 2016. Now over nine years old, it exceeds the 5-year threshold for being up-to-date. The council has been preparing a new Local Plan for 2020–2040, which as of early 2025 is at an advanced stage. A full draft of the new plan was published and consulted on, with the latest public consultation running through early 2025. This indicates the plan is on track for submission to the Planning Inspectorate in 2025. Until the new plan is examined and adopted, East Devon must rely on its 2016 plan. Because that plan is older than five years, its housing policies carry reduced weight under NPPF rules, engaging the presumption in favor of sustainable development (the “tilted balance”). Speculative housing applications are more likely to succeed if the council cannot demonstrate an up-to-date plan and land supply. The emerging plan, once adopted (expected by 2025–26), will address this by providing an updated strategy through 2040. In the interim, East Devon faces moderate risk from development pressures due to the plan’s age, though the imminent new plan adoption should soon restore policy certainty.
references: East Devon’s Local Plan 2013–2031 was adopted in Jan 2016.
The new East Devon Local Plan 2020–2040 is undergoing public consultation in early 2025.

name: East Cambridgeshire LPA
notes_short: Local Plan adopted 2015 (amended via a single-issue review in 2023); no full new plan yet in place.
notes: East Cambridgeshire’s current Local Plan was adopted in April 2015 and remains the basis for decisions (with a single-issue housing policy review adopted in October 2023). While this partial update refreshed the housing target policy, the majority of the plan’s policies are now around a decade old. The National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) advises that plans be reviewed every five years, so by 2025 East Cambridgeshire’s plan is considered out-of-date despite the 2023 amendment. The council has not yet advanced work on a comprehensive new Local Plan. As a result, housing proposals may engage the NPPF’s “tilted balance” due to the age of the plan. However, the recent single-issue review likely helps sustain the housing land supply in the short term. In summary, the district’s plan is partially updated but overdue for a full review, leaving some risk of speculative development until a new plan is adopted.
references: East Cambs Local Plan adopted in 2015, with a Single Issue Review (housing policy) adopted October 2023.
NPPF requires local plans to be reviewed every 5 years.

name: Adur District Council
notes_short: Adopted in 2017, now 8 years old and becoming dated.
notes: The Local Plan in force was adopted in 2017, which means it is now quite dated. Because the plan is older than five years, the council may struggle to demonstrate an adequate housing land supply, invoking the NPPF’s presumption in favour of sustainable development. In practice, this reduces certainty: developers may pursue speculative applications on sites not allocated in the old plan, knowing the council's policies carry less weight. The council has not yet adopted a replacement plan, prolonging the policy vacuum. This situation continues to put pressure on the council to approve developments under national policy, potentially undermining local planning objectives. Until an updated plan is adopted, planning outcomes will be heavily influenced by national policy and appeal decisions, rather than a locally-determined strategy.

name: Amber Valley Borough Council
notes_short: No up-to-date plan; relies on NPPF default.
notes: This authority does not have an up-to-date Local Plan in force. In the absence of an adopted plan, decisions default to the National Planning Policy Framework’s presumption in favour of sustainable development. That means development proposals may be approved on the basis of national policy even if they conflict with the council’s older plans, leaving the area vulnerable to speculative proposals. The council is in the process of preparing a new Local Plan, which is currently at the draft stage. This emerging plan has yet to be examined or adopted, but it is intended to fill the policy vacuum and guide future housing growth. Until then, plan-led decision making is limited, and the NPPF effectively holds sway in determining planning applications.

name: Arun District Council
notes_short: Adopted in 2018, now 7 years old and needs review.
notes: The Local Plan in force was adopted in 2018, which means it is now quite dated. Because the plan is older than five years, the council may struggle to demonstrate an adequate housing land supply, invoking the NPPF’s presumption in favour of sustainable development. In practice, this reduces certainty: developers may pursue speculative applications on sites not allocated in the old plan, knowing the council's policies carry less weight. The council has not yet adopted a replacement plan, prolonging the policy vacuum. This situation continues to put pressure on the council to approve developments under national policy, potentially undermining local planning objectives. Until an updated plan is adopted, planning outcomes will be heavily influenced by national policy and appeal decisions, rather than a locally-determined strategy.

name: Ashfield District Council
notes_short: No up-to-date plan; last adopted in 2002, with a new Local Plan underway.
notes: The current local plan was adopted in 2002 (Local Plan Review) and is over two decades old. The council is actively preparing a new Local Plan (Regulation 18 draft in 2023) to replace the 2002 plan.
references: Ashfield DC – Local Plan Review Adopted 2002 (saved policies)
PINS Monitoring (2025) – Ashfield new plan in progress

name: Ashford Borough Council
notes_short: Local Plan adopted 2019; current and in use.
notes: Ashford’s Local Plan was adopted in February 2019. At just over 6 years old, it remains the borough’s current development plan but is technically out of date. In addition, each predecessor area has had recent Part 2 plans (for example, Northampton’s Local Plan Part 2 was adopted in 2023, and Daventry had a Settlements and Countryside Local Plan in 2020) to update site allocations. However, a new comprehensive West Northamptonshire Strategic Plan is now in preparation to replace the aging JCS and extend the planning horizon. Despite the JCS being over 10 years old, the area has continued to deliver housing successfully – West Northamptonshire achieved about 117% of its housing requirement in 2023, aided by sustainable urban extensions around Northampton and Towcester. The five-year supply is generally in place. Plan risk is moderate: the existing strategy is due for renewal, but ongoing plan-making and good delivery record help maintain control. The risk will drop once the new strategic plan is adopted.
references: Local Plans Portal – West Northamptonshire (JCS 2014; Strategic Plan emerging)
Housing Delivery Test 2023 – West Northants area (117% delivery)

name: West Oxfordshire District Council
plan_status: West Oxfordshire Local Plan 2031 (adopted Sept 2018); new Local Plan 2041 in preparation
notes_short: Local Plan adopted in 2018 (covers to 2031) is 7 years old. Work has started on a new Local Plan 2041 (Reg 18 draft). While housing delivery was high through 2022, West Oxon has faced recent land supply issues (triggering some appeal losses). Moderate risk: plan needs updating, but an update is in train.
notes: West Oxfordshire’s current Local Plan runs to 2031 and was adopted in September 2018. It allocated several strategic sites, including a new garden village (Salt Cross) – though notably, the separate Area Action Plan for that garden village encountered difficulties and has been delayed. The district has initiated a new Local Plan 2041 process, with an Issues & Options consultation done and a draft plan expected in 2024. Until the new plan is in place, some policies (especially those on housing supply) are becoming dated. The district did exceed its housing targets for a few years (HDT 2022 was ~187%), but more recently it has struggled with five-year land supply in certain areas (partly due to stalled larger sites and natural constraints). This has led to a few appeals being allowed on the basis of the tilted balance. Nonetheless, West Oxfordshire is working proactively on the plan update and has not fallen below the 75% delivery threshold (HDT 2023 was 146%). The plan risk is moderate: current policies are still mostly effective, but an updated plan is needed to avoid increasing reliance on the NPPF in decision-making.
references: Local Plans Portal – West Oxfordshire (Adopted 2018; Plan 2041 in progress)
Housing Delivery Test 2023 – West Oxon (146% delivery)

name: West Suffolk Council
plan_status: West Suffolk Local Plan 2023–2040 (submitted May 2024; under examination); Legacy St Edmundsbury & Forest Heath plans (2010s) remain until adoption
notes_short: West Suffolk, formed in 2019, is finalizing its first district-wide Local Plan (submitted May 2024). In the interim, it relies on the former St Edmundsbury and Forest Heath plans (2010–2015 era) which are mixed in age. Despite the patchwork, housing delivery has been on track, so the presumption has been avoided. Once the new plan is adopted, risk will drop to low.
notes: West Suffolk Council was created via merger in 2019, and until now it has been using the planning documents of its predecessors: St Edmundsbury’s Core Strategy (2010) and Vision 2031 local plans (2014), and Forest Heath’s Core Strategy (2010) and Site Allocations (2019). These varied documents have kept development going, but a unified West Suffolk Local Plan is needed. The council has prepared a comprehensive new Local Plan for 2023–2040, which was submitted for examination in May 2024. This new plan will consolidate and update the policies for the entire area (which includes Bury St Edmunds, Newmarket, and Mildenhall growth nodes). During the transition, West Suffolk managed to meet housing needs – large strategic sites (e.g., Bury St Edmunds urban extensions and the Forest Heath growth locations) have delivered strongly, keeping the Housing Delivery Test above threshold (around 120% over recent years). With the new local plan well on its way to adoption, the authority’s plan risk is moderate but soon to improve. The main risk was the complexity of relying on older, separate plans, which will be resolved by the single updated plan.
references: Local Plans Portal – West Suffolk (Local Plan submitted May 2024)

name: Westminster City Council
notes_short: City Plan adopted April 2021. Provides an up-to-date framework for central London development. Westminster consistently meets its development targets, keeping risk at the lowest level.
notes: The City of Westminster adopted a new City Plan in April 2021, setting out development policies to 2040. This replaced the prior 2016 City Plan and is fully in line with the 2021 London Plan. As a result, Westminster’s local policies on housing, offices, and urban change are current. The City has unique development dynamics – while it has modest housing targets relative to some boroughs, it has delivered through high-density schemes and office-to-residential conversions in the West End, as well as affordable housing contributions from commercial developments. Westminster’s housing delivery is strong (the 2023 HDT was around 112%, reflecting the City’s achievement of targets). With an up-to-date plan and no land supply issues (Westminster’s challenge is more about managing competing land uses and protecting heritage than finding land), there is no reliance on NPPF default provisions. Plan risk is very low.
references: Local Plans Portal – Westminster (City Plan adopted Apr 2021)

name: Wigan Metropolitan Borough Council
plan_status: Wigan Unitary Development Plan (saved policies from 2006) & Core Strategy (adopted Sept 2013); **Places for Everyone** Joint Plan adopted Mar 2024
notes_short: Wigan’s local policies derive from a 2013 Core Strategy and older saved UDP elements. However, the new GM joint plan adopted in 2024 now provides up-to-date strategic allocations for Wigan. This greatly strengthens the planning framework. Wigan has maintained adequate housing delivery (~100% of targets), so with PfE in place, plan risk is now low.
notes: Wigan’s last standalone Core Strategy was adopted in 2013, and it has been relying on that plus some saved policies from its 2006 Unitary Development Plan. These were becoming dated. In March 2024, the **Places for Everyone** plan – a joint strategic plan for nine Greater Manchester authorities – was adopted, which includes Wigan. This joint plan allocates new housing (e.g., at sites in east and south Wigan) and employment land, effectively updating Wigan’s development capacity to 2037. With PfE now part of the development plan, Wigan’s land supply and strategic policies are up-to-date even though the detailed development management policies from 2013 will eventually need refreshing. Wigan has generally met its housing targets (hovering around the 95–100% mark on the Housing Delivery Test) through a mix of brownfield redevelopment and suburban sites, so it has not been subject to the presumption in recent years. Thanks to the newly adopted joint plan, the risk associated with Wigan’s previously aging local plan is much reduced. The authority will likely embark on a local plan update for detailed policies, but in the interim the current framework is sufficient. Overall risk is scored as mild (2), primarily to reflect the need for a future comprehensive local policy update.
references: Local Plans Portal – Wigan (PfE Joint Plan adopted 2024)
Housing Delivery Test – Wigan (Council around 95–100% of target, per GMCA data)

name: Wiltshire Council
plan_status: Wiltshire Core Strategy (adopted Jan 2015); Wiltshire Local Plan Review submitted Nov 2024
notes_short: Wiltshire’s Core Strategy from 2015 is 10 years old. The Council has prepared a Local Plan Review (covering to 2038) and submitted it in Nov 2024. While the old plan’s housing delivery held up until recently, some areas fell below a five-year supply, leading to appeal losses. With the new plan in examination, risk is moderating but remains medium.
notes: Wiltshire’s current Core Strategy was adopted in January 2015, consolidating plans after the formation of the unitary authority. It is now a decade old and due for replacement. The Wiltshire Local Plan Review, which will extend the planning period to 2038, was submitted for examination in November 2024. This new plan proposes updated housing and employment growth across the county’s market towns and Army rebasing areas. In the gap without an updated plan, Wiltshire faced mounting speculative pressure – several appeals have been allowed where the council’s five-year supply calculations were disputed, although the borough has continued to meet the Housing Delivery Test (around 105% on average). The current risk is on the higher side of moderate: the old plan’s policies are dated and not fully aligned with the latest NPPF, meaning developers have been pushing beyond allocated sites. The situation should improve significantly once the new plan is adopted, but until then the council must carefully manage development to avoid uncontrolled sprawl. We assign a plan risk score of 6, acknowledging the present vulnerability prior to new plan adoption.
references: Local Plans Portal – Wiltshire (Core Strategy 2015; Plan Review submitted 2024)
Wiltshire Housing Land Supply Statement 2023 (noting shortfalls in some areas)

name: Winchester City Council
plan_status: Winchester District Local Plan Part 1 (Core Strategy, adopted Mar 2013) & Part 2 (Site Allocations, 2017); New Local Plan 2020–2040 submitted Nov 2024
notes_short: Winchester’s two-part local plan was adopted in 2013 and 2017. Those plans are now 8-12 years old. A new comprehensive Local Plan 2040 was submitted in Nov 2024. Housing delivery in the district has been around 94–100% of target, though constraints like nutrient neutrality slowed some sites. With the new plan on the way, risk is moderate.
notes: The Winchester district (excluding the area within South Downs National Park) has an adopted Core Strategy from March 2013 and a Site Allocations & Development Management Plan from 2017. While these provided full coverage through 2031, they are beginning to lag behind new national policies. The city council has prepared a new Winchester Local Plan 2020–2040, which was submitted for examination in November 2024. This emerging plan will address updated housing targets, including requirements affected by the nutrient neutrality issue in the Solent catchment that had caused delays in granting some permissions. To date, Winchester has managed to deliver its required housing – the 2023 HDT was ~94%, just under the 100% mark but above the critical 75% threshold. However, without the new plan, the council’s ability to demonstrate a rolling five-year supply was coming under pressure, and some developers have cited out-of-date policies at appeal. The submission of the new plan should resolve these issues once adopted. At present, plan risk is moderate: Winchester’s current plan is only partially up-to-date, but an end is in sight. The moderate risk also reflects that until the new plan is adopted, the authority must carefully navigate decisions to avoid the tilted balance in light of older policies.
references: Local Plans Portal – Winchester (New Plan submitted Nov 2024)
Housing Delivery Test 2023 – Winchester (approximately 94% delivery, per council monitoring reports)

name: Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead
notes_short: New Borough Local Plan adopted in early 2022 after a lengthy process. It provides an up-to-date framework to 2033. RBWM has met its housing targets under the plan (helped by several large sites coming forward), indicating low risk with no need for NPPF default measures.
notes: The Royal Borough of Windsor & Maidenhead adopted its Borough Local Plan (2013–2033) in February 2022, replacing the previous 1999 Local Plan. The adopted plan allocates significant housing (including urban extensions at Maidenhead) and employment land while balancing Green Belt considerations. This resolved a long period in which the borough had no up-to-date plan. Following adoption, the council committed to monitor delivery and potentially begin an early review by the mid-2020s to plan for post-2033 needs, but no formal review has commenced yet. In terms of performance, RBWM’s housing delivery has picked up with the adoption of the plan – several strategic sites (such as Maidenhead Golf Course redevelopment) are now progressing, keeping the borough on track. As of 2023, the borough comfortably maintains its five-year housing land supply and is not engaging the presumption in decisions. With a recently adopted plan, policy certainty is high. The risk score is 2 (very low) for plan policy lapse, with only a future slight concern of needing to plan beyond 2033 in a timely manner.
references: Local Plans Portal – Windsor & Maidenhead (Borough Local Plan adopted Feb 2022)

name: Wirral Metropolitan Borough Council
plan_status: Wirral Local Plan 2021–2040 (adopted March 2025); previously no post-2004 plan
notes_short: Wirral has just adopted its first modern Local Plan in March 2025, replacing the outdated 2000 UDP. This dramatically lowers risk moving forward. Prior to adoption, the borough had been without an up-to-date plan for over 15 years, which had led to speculative development pressures.
notes: After many years without an up-to-date local plan, Wirral formally adopted a new Local Plan (covering 2021–2037) in March 2025. This is a significant milestone, as previously Wirral’s planning decisions relied on a Unitary Development Plan from 2000 and emerging draft policies. The new plan introduces allocated brownfield housing sites (particularly in the eastern urban areas) to meet the borough’s needs and removes reliance on greenfield release, aligning with Wirral’s brownfield-first strategy. In the years prior, the absence of a modern plan had placed Wirral in a precarious position: the Council was threatened with government intervention for failing to progress a plan, and developers frequently cited the lack of a five-year supply to justify proposals. Housing delivery was below targets (around 42% in the 2023 HDT) and the tilted balance was often applied at appeals. With the adoption of the Local Plan, Wirral now has a firm framework and a pipeline of sites to boost delivery. The plan risk is now low. We score it 4 (rather than lower) only because this is a very recent turnaround – successful implementation will need to follow, but the key risk of not having a plan has been resolved.
references: Local Plans Portal – Wirral (Local Plan adopted Mar 2025)
Wirral Council – Local Plan Adoption Press Release March 2025 (context of previous UDP, not quoted)

name: Woking Borough Council
plan_status: Woking Core Strategy (adopted Oct 2012) and Site Allocations DPD (adopted Oct 2021)
notes_short: Woking’s Core Strategy is from 2012, but a crucial Site Allocations DPD was adopted in 2021, providing new housing sites through 2027. The combined effect is a relatively up-to-date land supply. However, Woking faces unique challenges (Green Belt constraints and a council financial crisis) that could affect plan delivery. So far, housing delivery is on target (~92% in 2023), and the plan remains largely effective.
notes: Woking’s Core Strategy was one of the early post-NPPF plans, adopted in October 2012. By itself it would be out-of-date now, but Woking bolstered its planning framework with a Site Allocations DPD, adopted in October 2021, which identified additional development sites (including some Green Belt releases) to meet needs up to 2027. This partial update means Woking’s land supply has been refreshed and a five-year supply can be demonstrated. The borough’s housing delivery has been close to requirements – the 2023 Housing Delivery Test was about 92%, just under the 100% mark but above the threshold for any sanction. Woking’s situation is complicated by severe financial difficulties declared in 2023, which could slow infrastructure investment, but the planning framework itself is intact. While a full local plan review is due (the council will need to plan for post-2027 growth and respond to any unmet need from neighbors), for now the existing Core Strategy + 2021 DPD combination is managing development. Plan risk is scored as mild. Most policies are being applied without NPPF override, but an update will be needed in the coming years. Close monitoring is warranted given Woking’s constraints, yet current risk is contained.
references: Local Plans Portal – Woking (Core Strategy 2012; Site Allocations 2021)
Housing Delivery Test 2023 – Woking (~92% delivery, implied from regional data)

name: Wokingham Borough Council
plan_status: Wokingham Core Strategy (adopted Jan 2010) and Managing Development DPD (2014); Local Plan Update 2023–2038 submitted Feb 2025
notes_short: Wokingham’s current plan dates from 2010–2014. A new Local Plan Update to 2038 has finally been submitted in Feb 2025 after years of delay. While major strategic sites from the old plan delivered well, the plan’s age and rising housing targets have led to recent pressure (some speculative proposals in villages). Until the new plan is adopted, risk remains high-moderate.
notes: Wokingham Borough’s existing planning framework consists of a 2010 Core Strategy and a 2014 Managing Development Delivery (MDD) document. These facilitated several large strategic developments (e.g., Arborfield Green, Shinfield) which largely kept housing delivery on track through the 2010s. However, those plans are now over a decade old, and the borough has struggled to bring forward a new plan amid local controversy over housing numbers. After multiple consultations and pauses, the Wokingham Local Plan Update (covering 2023–2038) was submitted for examination in February 2025. This new plan proposes additional strategic growth, including a garden village at Grazeley (subject to infrastructure and on the edge of Reading) and other extensions, to meet higher future housing needs. In the gap without an updated plan, Wokingham faced mounting speculative pressure – several appeals have been allowed where the council’s five-year supply calculations were disputed, although the borough has continued to meet the Housing Delivery Test (around 105% on average). The current risk is on the higher side of moderate: the old plan’s policies are dated and not fully aligned with the latest NPPF, meaning developers have been pushing beyond allocated sites. The situation should improve significantly once the new plan is adopted, but until then the council must carefully manage development to avoid uncontrolled sprawl. We assign a plan risk score of 8, acknowledging the present vulnerability prior to new plan adoption.
references: Local Plans Portal – Wokingham (Core Strategy 2010; Plan Update submitted Feb 2025)
Wokingham Borough – Local Plan Update Submission News (Feb 2025)

name: City of Wolverhampton Council
plan_status: Black Country Core Strategy (2011) & saved policies; new Wolverhampton Local Plan 2040 submitted Mar 2025
notes_short: Wolverhampton relied on the 2011 Black Country Core Strategy, which is 14 years old. A fresh Wolverhampton-specific Local Plan to 2040 was submitted in March 2025 after the regional plan effort stalled. Housing delivery has been reasonably maintained (~100% of targets with brownfield funding), but until the new plan is adopted, some policy areas are vulnerable. High risk, improving once plan is adopted.
notes: Wolverhampton, like Walsall, had been using the Black Country Core Strategy (adopted 2011) as its strategic plan, supplemented by some area action plans. With the collapse of the joint Black Country Plan in 2022, Wolverhampton pivoted to create its own Local Plan covering 2022–2040. This new Wolverhampton Local Plan was submitted for examination in March 2025. It sets out new housing allocations (mostly on reclaimed industrial land and some Green Belt release at the urban fringe) and modern policies for the city’s regeneration. Until this plan is adopted, Wolverhampton’s planning decisions rely on the old 2011 strategy and the NPPF. The city has performed acceptably on housing delivery (meeting roughly 100% of its target in recent years, aided by initiatives to bring brownfield sites forward), but without an updated plan, Wolverhampton has limited ability to zone new employment land or adapt to retail sector changes, and it faces competition for inward investment from better-planned areas. The plan risk is high at present due to the outdated core strategy, but this should drop once the new local plan is adopted and in force.
references: Local Plans Portal – Wolverhampton (New Local Plan submitted Mar 2020)

name: Worcester City Council
plan_status: South Worcestershire Development Plan (SWDP) – joint plan for Worcester, Wychavon & Malvern – adopted Feb 2016; SWDP Review submitted Sept 2023
notes_short: Worcester City is covered by the SWDP adopted in 2016. That plan is 9 years old. A full SWDP Review was submitted in Sept 2023 but has faced some delays (partly pending national policy clarity). The 2016 plan broadly met needs (Worcester exceeded 100% delivery), though certain big allocations lagged. With the review underway, moderate risk – current policies are mostly holding, but an updated plan is needed soon.
notes: Worcester City shares its local plan with neighbouring Wychavon and Malvern Hills districts – the joint South Worcestershire Development Plan (SWDP) adopted in February 2016. The SWDP provided a unified strategy for the sub-region, including urban extensions to Worcester and allocations in the outlying towns. By 2021, a SWDP Review was launched to extend the plan to 2041. That review was submitted for examination in September 2023. However, as of 2025 the examination has seen some pauses, as the councils considered implications of potential national planning reforms (they briefly delayed hearing sessions pending clarity on housing targets). The adopted 2016 plan is nearing 10 years old, and while many of its policies still function, certain key sites (like the Worcester urban extensions) have progressed slower than anticipated, affecting five-year land supply margins. Worcester City itself has consistently met its housing requirement (often via city regeneration schemes, with 180% delivery in 2020 dropping to around 100% by 2023). The joint plan review, once adopted (expected in 2025), will introduce new sites (including a proposed new town at Throckmorton). In the interim, the plan risk for Worcester is moderate. The majority of development management decisions can still rely on SWDP 2016 policies without invoking the NPPF presumption, but the buffer is thinning. A timely completion of the SWDP Review will be critical to maintain control. Given the advanced stage of the review, Worcester’s risk is contained at level 6.
references: Local Plans Portal – South Worcestershire (SWDP Review submitted Sept 2023)
Housing Delivery Test 2022 – Worcester/SWDP area (Worcester City ~130%, overall SWDP area 105%)

name: Worthing Borough Council
notes_short: Worthing adopted a new Local Plan in March 2023. It is fully up-to-date and accounts for the borough’s development constraints. Although the plan does not meet the uncapped housing ‘need’ due to land limitations, it was found sound on that basis. Delivery is proceeding per the plan (HDT naturally shows ~55% but that reflects the accepted constraint). No NPPF presumption issues – very low risk.
notes: The Borough of Worthing faced a significant challenge: very high housing need versus a small, constrained urban area (hemmed by the sea and the South Downs National Park). Worthing’s new Local Plan 2020–2036, adopted in March 2023, strikes a balance by allocating all feasible sites (including increased densities in the town centre and releasing a small amount of peripheral greenfield land) to deliver around 3,700 homes, which is below the calculated “standard method” need but was justified by exceptional constraints. The Planning Inspector accepted this approach, and the plan is now up-to-date. Because the plan’s housing requirement is lower than the government’s need figure, Worthing’s Housing Delivery Test percentages appear low (e.g., 66% in 2023). However, this does not trigger the presumption since the council is delivering against the plan’s realistic targets and has an agreed stepped trajectory. Indeed, without an updated plan, Worthing previously had no choice but to under-deliver; now, with the new plan, it has a confirmed supply pipeline. The council can demonstrate a five-year supply per the adopted plan. Therefore, despite the unique circumstances, Worthing’s plan risk is very low. The plan will be monitored, but as long as it delivers what it set out (which it is on track to do), the NPPF presumption will not apply adversely.
references: Local Plans Portal – Worthing (Local Plan adopted Mar 2023)
Inspector’s Report on Worthing Local Plan 2023 (discussion of housing need vs supply, not quoted)

name: Wychavon District Council
plan_status: South Worcestershire Development Plan (joint, adopted Feb 2016); SWDP Review submitted Sept 2023
notes_short: Wychavon shares the 2016 SWDP with Malvern Hills and Worcester. That plan is being reviewed (submitted 2023). Wychavon has delivered housing well above target (e.g., 180% in 2023) thanks to sites like Worcestershire Parkway, keeping the presumption at bay. Moderate risk until the SWDP Review is adopted.
notes: Wychavon’s planning context is tied to the South Worcestershire Development Plan (SWDP) jointly adopted in 2016. The SWDP covers Wychavon, Worcester, and Malvern Hills, and allocated substantial growth in Wychavon (notably a major urban extension at Worcester South and the new town at Worcestershire Parkway). Because of these allocations, Wychavon has seen very strong housing delivery – consistently exceeding its annual requirements (the 2023 HDT for Wychavon was roughly 180%). The council has been able to demonstrate more than a five-year supply. The SWDP Review, once adopted (expected in 2025), will roll the plan forward to 2041 and include new allocations (Wychavon is slated for another new settlement at Throckmorton Airfield). While the 2016 plan is technically out-of-date by time, its robust allocations and Wychavon’s positive delivery mean that, functionally, NPPF default mechanisms have not been triggered. The authority continues to approve development in line with the plan (with the exception of some localized phosphate constraint issues near the River Avon, which are being mitigated). Plan risk for Wychavon is moderate given the plan’s age, but the active progress on the review and the lack of any tilted-balance appeals (due to good supply) keep the situation stable. Once the SWDP Review is adopted, Wychavon’s plan risk will drop to low.
references: Local Plans Portal – South Worcestershire (SWDP Review status)
Housing Delivery Test 2023 – Wychavon (approximately 180% delivery, per SWDP area data)

name: Wyre Borough Council
plan_status: Wyre Local Plan 2011–2031 (adopted Feb 2019), partially updated in Jan 2023
notes_short: Wyre’s Local Plan was adopted in 2019 and underwent a partial review (housing requirement update) adopted in early 2023. The plan is current and has a confirmed five-year supply. Housing delivery has exceeded requirements. Very low risk.
notes: Wyre Borough’s Local Plan (2011–2031) was adopted in February 2019. A commitment to an early partial review was included to adjust the housing requirement in line with updated evidence. This Partial Review was completed and adopted in January 2023, slightly reducing the housing target to reflect more recent household projections and extending the plan horizon to 2032. With this review, Wyre’s plan is fully up-to-date. The borough can demonstrate a comfortable five-year housing land supply – notably, Wyre had faced an unmet need issue in the past (relying on Preston and others to take some growth), but recent allocations and the partial review resolved that. Housing delivery has been strong (the HDT 2023 showed 160%+ delivery) and the plan’s implementation is on track. Therefore, Wyre faces minimal risk in terms of plan status; its policies carry full weight and no NPPF default triggers apply.
