The next plan update will likely start before 2031, but at present the planning framework is secure.
references: Local Plans Portal – Wyre (Local Plan adopted 2019; Partial Update 2023)

name: Wyre Forest District Council
plan_status: Wyre Forest Local Plan (Review) 2016–2036, adopted April 2022
notes_short: A new Wyre Forest Local Plan was adopted in April 2022, replacing the previous 2004-era plan. It is up-to-date and provides for development to 2036 (including a significant urban extension at Kidderminster). Housing delivery is on target with the plan’s trajectory. Low risk.
notes: Wyre Forest District adopted its Local Plan Review in April 2022. This new plan covers the period 2016–2036 and succeeded the old Local Plan (adopted 2004). It allocates major growth, notably the Kidderminster Eastern extension (Lea Castle) and brownfield regeneration sites, to meet the district’s needs. With this adoption, Wyre Forest regained a five-year housing supply and updated policy control. The plan is only about 3 years into implementation and remains fully aligned with national policy. Early monitoring shows housing delivery ramping up as the strategic sites begin to build out (the Housing Delivery Test is not a concern, as completions are expected to meet or slightly exceed annual requirements going forward). Because the plan is newly in place and there are no significant shortfalls or policy gaps, the plan risk for Wyre Forest is very low. The council will keep the plan under review, but no update is needed yet.
references: Local Plans Portal – Wyre Forest (Local Plan Review adopted Apr 2022)

name: City of York Council
plan_status: City of York Local Plan 2017–2033 (adopted February 2025)
notes_short: York’s Local Plan was famously long-delayed but was finally adopted in early 2025. It is the first comprehensive development plan for York in over 60 years. With this fresh plan in place (including defined Green Belt boundaries and ample housing sites), York’s framework is solid and risk is very low.
notes: After a protracted process spanning nearly two decades, the City of York formally adopted a Local Plan in February 2025. York had been operating without an adopted post-2004 plan, relying only on a development control Local Plan from 1956 and emerging drafts. The new Local Plan 2017–2033 provides certainty on Green Belt boundaries around York and allocates several large sites (such as the York Central brownfield site and strategic expansions at Clifton Moor and Elvington). This marks a turning point – previously, the lack of a plan meant the presumption in favor of development often applied by default, but now York has a full policy framework. Housing delivery in York has been strong in recent years even without a plan (the 2023 HDT was about 120%), and the new plan will support continued delivery with clearer infrastructure commitments. With an up-to-date plan, York can manage development proactively rather than reacting under NPPF defaults. The plan risk is therefore assessed as very low (1). The council will need to keep the plan under review in line with statutory requirements, but having just adopted it, York is in an excellent position moving forward.
references: Local Plans Portal – York (Local Plan adopted Feb 2025)
City of York Council – Local Plan Adoption Press Release Feb 2025 (historical context, not quoted)

name: Yorkshire Dales National Park Authority
plan_status: Yorkshire Dales Local Plan 2015–2030 (adopted Dec 2016); New Local Plan 2025–2040 in draft (publication Mar 2025)
notes_short: The Yorkshire Dales National Park’s current local plan was adopted in 2016. It is now under revision; a draft new Local Plan 2025–2040 was published in March 2025. The National Park has modest development needs and stringent protections, so while the plan is older, development pressure is low and handled via restrictive policies – moderate risk.
notes: The Yorkshire Dales National Park Authority adopted its Local Plan 2015–2030 in December 2016. This plan set very limited growth targets consistent with National Park purposes (focusing on local needs housing and barn conversions). As of 2025, the plan is being updated: the Authority published a draft Local Plan 2025–2040 in March 2025, which will eventually supersede the 2016 plan. Given the National Park’s context, the lack of a completely up-to-date plan has not led to significant issues – development rates are very low and tightly controlled. Housing Delivery Test measures are not applicable in the usual way due to small numbers, and the NPPF affords great weight to conservation in National Parks which continues to guide decisions. Essentially, even though the plan is older than 5 years, its restrictive approach remains aligned with national policy for protected landscapes. The forthcoming plan will adjust policies to new challenges (like sustainability and climate change adaptation for the park) and extend the timeframe. Plan risk is moderate largely from a procedural standpoint; practically, there is little risk of unwanted development in the interim. Once the new plan is adopted, the risk will drop, but even under the current plan the National Park’s policy environment is stable.

name: County Durham LPA
plan_status: County Durham Plan adopted in October 2020 (covering 2016–2035)
notes_short: Adopted a new County Durham Plan in 2020, providing an up-to-date development framework until 2035.
notes: Durham County Council adopted the County Durham Plan on 21 October 2020, which guides development in the county up to 2035. This replaced the patchwork of older local plans and provides current strategic policies for housing, jobs and infrastructure. At under 5 years old, the plan is considered up-to-date. The council is not yet undertaking a full review, aside from the legally required 5-year assessment by 2025. The adopted plan allocates sufficient land (with a housing supply up to 2035) and Durham has maintained its housing delivery, so NPPF para 11(d) 'tilted balance' does not automatically apply. No new Local Plan is being prepared at this time.

name: Darlington LPA
notes_short: Darlington’s Local Plan was adopted in 2022 and remains up-to-date, setting growth strategy to 2036.
notes: Darlington Borough Council adopted the Darlington Local Plan 2016–2036 in February 2022. This plan provides an up-to-date framework for development needs (housing, employment, etc.) through 2036. Being only 3 years old, it is well within the 5-year currency period. The council is not currently preparing a new plan or full review yet, given the plan’s recent adoption. Darlington has identified sufficient housing land and passed recent Housing Delivery Tests, so the NPPF’s presumption in favor of development is not triggered by any plan shortfall.

name: Hartlepool LPA
plan_status: Hartlepool Local Plan 2016–2031 adopted May 2018; no new plan yet
notes_short: Hartlepool’s Local Plan (adopted 2018) is over 5 years old with no replacement yet, making some policies out-of-date.
notes: Hartlepool Borough Council adopted its Local Plan on 22 May 2018, covering the period 2016–2031. Now 7 years old, it exceeds the 5-year threshold without a review, so its strategic policies are deemed out-of-date under NPPF 11(d). The council confirmed it is *not* currently reviewing the plan, focusing instead on monitoring implementation (e.g. publishing a 5-year housing land supply review). While the 2018 Plan still guides decisions, Hartlepool likely has to apply the NPPF’s tilted balance in determining applications due to the plan’s age. No emerging replacement plan is in progress yet, increasing uncertainty for developers (though the borough can demonstrate a 5-year housing land supply).

name: Gateshead LPA
plan_status: Core Strategy (2015) in place; New Gateshead Local Plan 2025–2045 in early preparation
notes_short: Gateshead’s current Core Strategy (Joint with Newcastle, adopted 2015) is 10 years old. A new Gateshead Plan 2025–2045 is underway (Regulation 18 consultation held in late 2023).
notes: Gateshead’s development plan is presently the Core Strategy and Urban Core Plan for Gateshead & Newcastle (adopted March 2015), which runs to 2030. This plan is now a decade old. A review in 2020 concluded it was up-to-date, but the council has since commenced a new Local Plan to extend the horizon to 2045. In November 2023 Gateshead launched a Reg.18 consultation on the Gateshead Plan 2025–2045. Until the new plan is adopted (expected by ~2025–26), Gateshead relies on its 2015 policies, which means parts of the NPPF’s default ‘presumption’ apply due to the plan’s age. The emerging plan aims to address updated needs (housing, climate, etc.) well into the 2040s. In the interim, housing applications may be judged against NPPF if the existing policies are deemed out-of-date, although the Council maintains it has a 5-year housing land supply.

name: Cheshire East LPA
plan_status: Local Plan Strategy adopted July 2017; Site Allocations DPD adopted Dec 2022; New Local Plan Update 2028–2043 in early stages
notes_short: Cheshire East’s strategic Local Plan (2017) is 8 years old, though site allocations were updated in 2022. A comprehensive Local Plan Update for 2028–2043 is now being prepared.
notes: Cheshire East’s current Local Plan comprises the Local Plan Strategy 2010–2030 (adopted July 2017) and a Site Allocations & Development Policies document adopted in December 2022. While the allocations piece is recent, the core strategy is 8 years old, prompting the Council to begin a new Local Plan Update 2028–2043. Initial public consultation on issues took place in 2024. The new plan will replace the 2017 Strategy to address growth beyond 2030 and incorporate updated housing targets and policies (e.g. environmental objectives). Until the new plan is in place (targeted by 2027–28), Cheshire East’s strategic policies (2017) risk being treated as out-of-date under NPPF 11d. However, the 2022 adoption of Part 2 mitigates some gaps (it updated development management policies and rolled forward some housing allocations). The authority must still monitor 5-year land supply and delivery to avoid the tilted balance in decisions. Overall risk is moderate, as an update is underway but not expected to conclude for several years.

name: Cheshire West and Chester LPA
plan_status: Local Plan (Part One) adopted Jan 2015, Part Two adopted July 2019; New Local Plan in preparation (per Jan 2024 decision)
notes_short: Cheshire West & Chester’s strategic plan dates to 2015 (with a 2019 Part 2). The council agreed in Jan 2024 to begin a new style Local Plan, as the current one is aging.
notes: The Cheshire West and Chester Local Plan is currently in two parts: the Part One: Strategic Policies (adopted January 2015) and the Part Two: Land Allocations & Detailed Policies (adopted 18 July 2019). While Part Two refreshed some aspects in 2019, the strategic policies are now a decade old. In January 2024, the Council formally decided to prepare a new Local Plan under the latest legislation. This new plan (still in early stages) will replace both Part One and Part Two to extend the planning horizon and update housing/employment targets. Until it is in place, the 2015/2019 plan remains the development plan. However, because the core strategy is >5 years old, the authority must monitor whether policies remain up-to-date – any significant housing land shortfall or delivery failure could trigger NPPF’s presumption. With a new plan not expected until around 2026–27, Cheshire West’s policy framework faces some uncertainty, but ongoing land supply management aims to mitigate speculative development risks.

name: Halton LPA
plan_status: Halton Delivery and Allocations Local Plan (DALP) adopted March 2022
notes_short: Halton’s borough-wide Local Plan was updated in 2022, consolidating its Core Strategy and allocations. It remains up-to-date and provides a framework to 2037.
notes: Halton Borough Council adopted the Delivery and Allocations Local Plan (DALP) in March 2022. This single plan incorporates a review of the 2013 Core Strategy and identifies site allocations, extending the planning horizon to 2037. At just 3 years old, the plan’s policies are current, and Halton is not yet undertaking a new review. The DALP adoption resolved prior gaps and provides a 15-year land supply. As such, Halton is not subject to the NPPF’s default presumption due to plan age or land supply (the borough passed the 2022 Housing Delivery Test and has identified a five-year housing supply). The next full plan review will likely commence by 2027 (five years from adoption) as required by legislation, but for now Halton’s planning policy is low-risk.

name: Bury LPA
plan_status: No recent standalone Local Plan (last was UDP 1997); Relying on Places for Everyone Joint Plan adopted March 2024; new Bury Local Plan (Part 2) in draft
notes_short: Bury had no up-to-date local plan until the Places for Everyone joint plan was adopted in 2024. That new strategic plan now forms Bury’s development plan (with the old 1997 UDP for detailed policies) while a new Bury Local Plan is being prepared.
notes: Bury’s last individual Local Plan was the Unitary Development Plan of 1997, meaning the borough lacked a modern plan for over two decades. In March 2024, Bury (with 8 other Greater Manchester districts) adopted the Places for Everyone (PfE) Joint Development Plan, which sets out strategic policies and allocations to 2037. PfE is now in force for Bury, filling the strategic policy vacuum and superseding many outdated elements. However, detailed development control in Bury still relies on saved UDP policies until a new local (Part 2) plan is adopted. The Council has already published a draft Bury Local Plan to provide local-level policies and replace the 1997 UDP. That plan is currently in consultation and expected to be submitted in 2024–25. In summary, while Bury’s strategic planning context is now up-to-date thanks to PfE (and thus not subject to NPPF default), the authority is actively updating local policies to complete its development plan framework.

name: Chorley LPA
plan_status: Central Lancashire Core Strategy adopted July 2012; Chorley Site Allocations Plan adopted 2015; New Central Lancs Local Plan (2023–2040) in Reg 19 consultation
notes_short: Chorley’s current plan is based on the 2012 Central Lancashire Core Strategy (plus a 2015 Chorley Local Plan). These are significantly outdated, but a new joint Central Lancashire Local Plan is well underway (Regulation 19 published Feb 2025).
notes: Chorley Borough, along with Preston and South Ribble, shares the Central Lancashire Core Strategy 2010–2026 adopted in July 2012. Chorley also has a Local Plan (Site Allocations and Development Management Policies) adopted in 2015. These plans are now well over 5 years old, and housing targets in them have been surpassed, leading to several successful planning appeals in recent years. A new Central Lancashire Local Plan 2023–2040 is in preparation to replace the 2012/2015 documents – a Publication draft was issued for consultation in Feb 2025. Submission is expected later in 2025. Until adoption (likely by 2026), Chorley remains vulnerable under NPPF’s tilted balance: the council has struggled to demonstrate a 5-year housing land supply with the old plan, and the out-of-date policies mean presumption in favor of sustainable development often applies. The emerging joint plan will reset requirements and allocate new sites. In the interim, plan risk is high, mitigated only by the advanced stage of the new plan.

name: Fylde LPA
plan_status: Fylde Local Plan to 2032 adopted October 2018 (partially reviewed Dec 2021)
notes_short: Fylde’s Local Plan (2018) was subject to an early Partial Review, adopted in Dec 2021, so it remains up-to-date. No new plan is currently in preparation.
notes: Fylde Borough Council adopted the Fylde Local Plan to 2032 in October 2018, and then adopted a Partial Review of it in December 2021. The Partial Review updated housing requirements in line with the Standard Method and aligned with the neighbouring Wyre and Blackpool plans. Because of this recent review, Fylde’s plan policies are considered up-to-date. The plan runs to 2032 and provides for a 5-year housing supply (the 2022 Authority Monitoring Report confirms a deliverable supply above requirements). There is no full Local Plan update in progress yet; Fylde will likely commence a new plan after 2025 to extend the timeframe beyond 2032. In the meantime, the 2018/2021 plan is robust under NPPF, and the tilted balance is not engaged (the borough also met the 2022 Housing Delivery Test). Plan risk is low.

name: Hyndburn LPA
plan_status: Hyndburn Core Strategy adopted 2012; New Hyndburn Local Plan 2040 submitted March 2025 (awaiting examination)
notes_short: Hyndburn’s current plan relies on a 2012 Core Strategy. A comprehensive new Local Plan (2023–2040) has now been submitted in March 2025 to replace it, which should resolve the long-standing policy vacuum once adopted.
notes: Hyndburn Borough’s development plan is outdated: the Core Strategy was adopted in January 2012, with some Development Management DPD policies added in 2018. The council has been working on a new Hyndburn Local Plan 2023–2040, which includes strategic policies and site allocations. This new plan was submitted for examination in March 2025. It will supersede the 2012 strategy and allocate sufficient land for housing and employment to 2040. Until the new plan is adopted (likely in 2026), Hyndburn’s 13-year-old policies carry reduced weight. The borough has frequently been unable to demonstrate a 5-year housing land supply under the old targets, triggering NPPF’s tilted balance in recent appeals. The plan review delay increased the risk of speculative applications. With submission achieved, however, the plan risk trajectory is improving – once inspectors find the new plan sound, Hyndburn will regain control with up-to-date policies. For now, though, the authority remains in a vulnerable position due to the aged Core Strategy.

name: Kingston upon Hull, City of LPA
plan_status: Hull Local Plan 2016–2032 adopted November 2017; New Local Plan to 2040 under development (Reg 18 consultation early 2025)
notes_short: Hull’s Local Plan (adopted 2017) is 8 years old. The council is now preparing a new Local Plan up to 2040, with public engagement ongoing in 2025.
notes: Hull City Council’s current Local Plan was adopted on 23 November 2017, covering the period 2016–2032. It established a strategy for housing growth, employment land and regeneration in the city. By 2025, the plan’s policies are 8 years old, so a full review is underway. Hull launched a Local Plan 2040 preparation process, with an engagement on issues and challenges open until April 2025. The new plan will address updated needs (including higher housing targets from the new standard method) and extend the plan period to 2040. In the interim, Hull’s 2017 plan remains the statutory basis for decisions, but its housing requirement has had to be adjusted to current figures. The council has continued to demonstrate a 5-year housing supply and passed the Housing Delivery Test, but because the plan is >5 years old, the NPPF presumption can apply if relevant policies are deemed out-of-date. Once the new plan is adopted (anticipated ~2026), Hull will regain a fully up-to-date framework. Plan risk in the short term is moderate due to the plan’s age, though mitigated by the active progress on the replacement plan.

name: Doncaster LPA
notes_short: Doncaster adopted a new Local Plan in 2021 covering to 2035. It remains up-to-date and is not yet due for replacement, though a 5-year review will occur by 2026.
notes: Doncaster Metropolitan Borough Council adopted the Doncaster Local Plan 2015–2035 in September 2021. This comprehensive plan guides development and growth across Doncaster, including major housing allocations (such as at Edlington and Thorne) and employment sites to meet needs up to 2035. At only ~4 years since adoption, the plan is firmly up-to-date under NPPF terms. The Council will carry out a review by 2026 to check if any policies need updating, but no new local plan is in progress yet. The current plan provides a sufficient housing land supply (Doncaster has about a 6.8-year supply per the latest monitoring) and the borough met the Housing Delivery Test in 2022, so there is no default ‘tilted balance’ situation. Plan risk is low; any issues (e.g. if future housing delivery falls behind) would be managed through the built-in monitoring and review mechanisms rather than an immediate plan overhaul.

name: Calderdale LPA
notes_short: Calderdale adopted a long-delayed Local Plan in 2023. It is very recent and up-to-date, providing a development framework to 2033 (with an early review policy by 2028).
notes: After a protracted examination, Calderdale’s new Local Plan was formally adopted in March 2023. This plan allocates large housing sites (including Garden Suburbs at Brighouse) and sets a strategy for growth to 2033. It replaces Calderdale’s earlier RCUDP (2006 Replacement Plan). Because the plan is only 2 years old, it is squarely up-to-date. The Inspector, however, required Calderdale to commit to an early review – Policy IM4 of the plan states that a review will be submitted by end of 2028. For now, no new plan is being drafted; the Council is focused on implementation (it recently demonstrated a 5-year housing supply using the new plan’s targets). With the plan adopted, Calderdale passed the 2023 Housing Delivery Test (achieving ~150% of target). Therefore, NPPF default provisions do not apply. The plan substantially reduces development risk in the borough after years of speculative applications during the plan hiatus.

name: Derby LPA
plan_status: Derby City Local Plan Part 1 (Core Strategy) adopted January 2017; No Part 2; New Local Plan 2021–2040 in preparation
notes_short: Derby’s current Local Plan is only Part 1 (2017 Core Strategy). Part 2 was never completed. The city has started work on a new Local Plan to cover 2021–2040, with initial scoping under way.
notes: Derby City’s Core Strategy (Local Plan Part 1) was adopted in January 2017. This plan guides strategic growth to 2028 but did not allocate all sites (the intended Part 2 plan was dropped). As of 2025 the Core Strategy is 8 years old, so Derby has begun preparing a new Local Plan (covering 2021–2040). Early visioning and “City Conversations” took place in 2022, and a Regulation 18 consultation is expected in 2025. In the meantime, the 2017 plan’s policies still apply for most of Derby, but some are out-of-date (e.g. housing figures). The city relies on adjacent districts (South Derbyshire, Amber Valley) for some housing via aligned strategies, and those plans are also under review. With no Part 2, some smaller allocations are handled case-by-case, increasing reliance on NPPF for determining certain applications. Derby has worked to maintain a 5-year land supply using the standard method for housing need, yet the plan’s age triggers the tilted balance for speculative proposals on unallocated sites. The emerging plan is crucial to extend Derby’s planning horizon and update its policies. Until adoption (likely ~2026/27), plan risk remains medium-high.

name: Chesterfield LPA
plan_status: Chesterfield Borough Local Plan 2018–2033 adopted July 2020
notes_short: Chesterfield’s Local Plan was adopted in 2020 and remains within the 5-year “up-to-date” window. It provides growth direction to 2033, with no new plan needed yet aside from a standard 5-year review by 2025.
notes: Chesterfield Borough Council adopted its Local Plan on 29 July 2020, setting out development allocations and policies to cover 2018–2033. This plan replaced the 2005 Local Plan and introduced new housing and employment sites (e.g. at Staveley and around the town periphery). As of 2025, the plan is exactly 5 years old. The Council is currently undertaking a 5-year review of the plan’s policies to confirm they remain fit for purpose. No substantive new Local Plan is in progress, as the existing one is largely up-to-date and the growth strategy remains valid. Chesterfield has a robust housing land supply (the 2023 monitoring report showed over 7 years supply) and met recent delivery tests. Thus, the NPPF presumption is not engaged. The main focus is implementing the 2020 plan, including major regeneration projects (such as the Staveley corridor) and monitoring infrastructure delivery. Plan risk is low at present, though an update may be considered around 2028 to extend the plan beyond 2033.

name: Derbyshire Dales LPA
plan_status: Derbyshire Dales Local Plan 2013–2033 adopted December 2017; Full Plan Review underway
notes_short: Derbyshire Dales’ Local Plan was adopted in 2017. Now 8 years old, the District is actively reviewing it – an emerging Local Plan Review (to cover beyond 2033) is in progress with consultation ongoing.
notes: Derbyshire Dales District Council’s current Local Plan (adopted December 2017) guides development to 2033. Key housing sites around Matlock, Wirksworth and Ashbourne were allocated, but delivery has been challenging, and some targets (e.g. 5680 homes by 2033) may not be met on time. Recognizing the need to keep the plan up-to-date, the Council commenced a Local Plan Review in 2021. An Initial Issues & Options consultation occurred, and work is underway on a preferred options draft. This new plan will likely extend to 2041 and adjust housing numbers. As of 2025, with the existing plan >5 years old and housing delivery below requirement (HDT was ~70% in 2022), relevant policies are deemed out-of-date. Indeed, Derbyshire Dales has been applying the tilted balance for housing proposals since the plan’s 5-year anniversary. The plan review aims to address this by adopting a new plan (target 2025–26). Until then, the authority is somewhat vulnerable to speculative development, though the Peak District National Park covers a portion of the district (limiting where development pressure is focused).

name: High Peak LPA
plan_status: High Peak Local Plan 2016 adopted April 2016; No replacement yet started
notes_short: High Peak’s Borough Local Plan was adopted in 2016 and is now 9 years old. The Council has not initiated a new plan review yet, leaving an aging policy framework (especially as the plan period is 2016–2031).
notes: High Peak Borough’s Local Plan was adopted on 14 April 2016, setting out development allocations and policies through 2031. This plan coordinated with the Peak District National Park Authority (which covers part of the borough) to direct growth mainly to Buxton, Glossop, and Chapel-en-le-Frith. As of 2025, the plan is nearly a decade old and in need of review. However, to date High Peak BC has not published a new Local Plan timetable, likely due to awaiting national policy changes. The 2016 plan is therefore increasingly misaligned with updated housing need figures (Standard Method indicates a higher annual requirement than the plan planned for). The council has maintained a 5-year housing supply by bringing forward reserve sites, but several appeal decisions have cited the plan’s age to apply NPPF’s presumption. The risk of speculative development is rising, particularly around Glossop (close to Manchester) where demand is strong. High Peak will be required to formally assess the plan by 2026; failing to start a review soon could lead to intervention. Plan risk is high until a review commences.

name: Charnwood LPA
plan_status: Charnwood Core Strategy 2011–2028 adopted Nov 2015; New Local Plan 2021–2037 submitted Dec 2021 (examination ongoing)
notes_short: Charnwood’s Core Strategy from 2015 is out-of-date. A new Charnwood Local Plan (covering 2021–37) was submitted in Dec 2021 but has faced delays in examination, leaving a planning gap.
notes: Charnwood Borough’s current adopted plan is the Core Strategy 2011–2028 (adopted November 2015). It set a framework for Loughborough and Shepshed growth, but its end date of 2028 and the housing requirement (based on older evidence) mean it no longer reflects current needs. Charnwood prepared a comprehensive new Local Plan for 2021–2037, which was submitted for examination in December 2021. However, examination has been protracted – by 2024 inspectors had raised concerns about soundness (notably over Leicester’s unmet need distribution and environmental constraints), and the process was paused pending clarity from national policy changes. Meanwhile, the 2015 Core Strategy is over 5 years old, so its housing policies are considered out-of-date. Charnwood does not have a confirmed 5-year land supply (in 2022 it was ~3.04 years), so the tilted balance is routinely invoked. This has led to approvals of large housing schemes on unallocated sites. The plan vacuum will persist until the new Local Plan is adopted (potentially in 2025 if issues are resolved). Plan risk is high due to the uncertainty and current policy weakness, although the emerging plan is at an advanced stage awaiting modifications.

name: Harborough LPA
plan_status: Harborough Local Plan 2011–2031 adopted April 2019; New Local Plan 2020–2041 under development (Reg18)
notes_short: Harborough’s Local Plan was adopted in 2019. It included a commitment to an early review to plan jointly for Leicester’s unmet housing. The Council has indeed started work on a New Local Plan 2020–2041, now in draft form.
notes: Harborough District Council adopted its current Local Plan in April 2019, covering 2011–2031. That plan allocated major sites (e.g. Lutterworth East SDA) but acknowledged Leicester’s unmet housing need would require an update. As a result, Harborough is among the partners in preparing a South West Leicestershire Growth Strategy and has commenced a new Local Plan (to extend to 2041). An initial ‘new Local Plan 2020–2041’ scoping consultation took place in 2022. By 2025, a draft plan is in the works, but not yet at examination. The 2019 plan is now 6 years old, so its housing policies are technically out-of-date; however Harborough can demonstrate a healthy land supply (over 7 years) which gives some protection. The council also passed the latest Housing Delivery Test (delivering ~120% of target). Still, because of the plan’s age and the commitment to an update, decisions on new large sites consider the emerging context. The status is unique: Harborough’s plan is relatively recent but already being updated. Risk is moderate – the adopted plan is largely operative, but upcoming higher targets from Leicester’s redistribution mean growth pressures are on the horizon.

name: Hinckley and Bosworth LPA
plan_status: Core Strategy adopted 2009 and Site Allocations DPD 2016; New Local Plan 2020–2041 in progress (was delayed, now aiming for adoption 2025)
notes_short: Hinckley & Bosworth’s plan is one of the oldest – a 2009 Core Strategy. A new Local Plan 2020–41 was drafted but its submission was delayed in 2022 due to national policy uncertainty. A revised plan (extended to 2041) is now on track for submission by mid-2025 under transitional rules.
notes: Hinckley and Bosworth Borough’s Core Strategy was adopted in December 2009, and a Site Allocations & DM Policies DPD followed in 2016. This framework is severely dated (the Core Strategy’s end date was 2026). The Council prepared a new Local Plan covering 2020–2041 and held a Regulation 19 consultation in early 2022, but they postponed submission in September 2022 citing the change of Prime Minister and pending planning reforms. The Local Development Scheme was updated in Dec 2022 to extend the plan period to 2041 and target adoption by August 2025. As of 2025, H&B is finalizing this plan for submission before the June 2025 LURB transition deadline. In the absence of an up-to-date plan, development management relies on outdated policies – the borough has struggled with speculative applications, especially for housing in rural villages, as it cannot demonstrate a sufficient land supply. In fact, by late 2022 the Council had to pause some decisions pending interim arrangements. Once the new plan is adopted, it will significantly lower risk by allocating ample housing (including a new settlement at Jennings) and updating Green Belt boundaries. Until then, the plan vacuum continues to force reliance on NPPF. Overall risk is very high, though mitigation is on the horizon with the emerging plan.

name: Lincoln LPA
plan_status: Central Lincolnshire Local Plan (joint) reviewed and adopted April 2023
notes_short: The City of Lincoln is covered by the joint Central Lincolnshire Local Plan, which was recently updated in 2023. It is fully up-to-date with an extended horizon to 2040, so no new plan work is needed currently.
notes: City of Lincoln Council, together with North Kesteven and West Lindsey, adopted the Central Lincolnshire Local Plan (Review) in April 2023. This plan replaced the 2017 version and runs to 2040, allocating significant growth around Lincoln (e.g. Sustainable Urban Extensions north of Lincoln) to meet housing needs. Because it was just adopted, it is an up-to-date plan under NPPF. The plan includes policies addressing climate change (it’s one of the first to have a net-zero carbon requirement for new development). The joint strategic planning team will monitor delivery, but no immediate review is expected until at least 2028. The City of Lincoln itself has a substantial housing supply identified through urban regeneration sites and urban extensions in the plan, and the area passed the latest Housing Delivery Test. With the new plan in place, Lincoln is not subject to defaulting – the plan’s policies carry full weight. The planning focus is now on implementation of allocated sites (e.g. the Western Growth Corridor within Lincoln). Plan risk is very low.

name: Gedling LPA
plan_status: Greater Nottingham Aligned Core Strategy (Part 1) adopted Sep 2014; Gedling Local Plan Part 2 adopted July 2018; Joint Strategic Plan Review (Greater Nottingham 2022–2040) underway
notes_short: Gedling’s strategic policies come from the 2014 Aligned Core Strategy, now 11 years old. A local Part 2 plan was done in 2018. Currently, a new Greater Nottingham Strategic Plan is being prepared to update the Part 1, and Gedling will likely follow with a Part 2 review.
notes: Gedling Borough is part of the Greater Nottingham joint planning arrangement. Its Aligned Core Strategy (ACS) was adopted in September 2014, covering Broxtowe, Nottingham City, and Gedling. Gedling then adopted a Local Planning Document (Part 2 Local Plan) in July 2018 to allocate sites and detail policies. The ACS (Part 1) is now 11 years old, and a joint Greater Nottingham Strategic Plan is in progress to replace it. A Publication Draft of this new strategic plan (for 2022–2040) was published in late 2024, with submission expected in 2025. It will set new housing targets for Gedling (likely increased to address Nottingham’s unmet need) and broad allocations. Once that is adopted, Gedling will update or replace its 2018 Part 2 plan to align with new strategic policies and extend site allocations further. In the interim, Gedling’s 2018 Part 2 provides some up-to-date development management policies, but the housing requirement in the 2014 ACS is superseded by the Standard Method. Gedling has struggled with housing delivery (2022 HDT was 75%, just on the threshold) and has had to use NPPF’s tilted balance on some applications. The emerging joint plan should resolve strategic issues by 2025, but currently the mix of older ACS and somewhat newer Part 2 yields a moderate risk planning context.

name: Herefordshire, County of LPA
plan_status: Herefordshire Local Plan Core Strategy 2011–2031 adopted October 2015; New Local Plan 2021–2041 in preparation (Reg18 consultation done)
notes_short: Herefordshire’s Core Strategy (2015) is now 10 years old and out-of-date. The Council is well advanced in producing a replacement Local Plan 2021–41, with Reg 18 consultations in 2022–23 and a Pre-submission draft expected in 2024.
notes: Herefordshire Council’s current Local Plan is the Core Strategy 2011–2031, adopted in October 2015. It provided a rural-focused growth strategy (with housing targets for the market towns and rural service centers). The Core Strategy is now in need of replacement. Work on a new Herefordshire Local Plan 2021–2041 began in 2021; an initial Issues and Options was done, and a preferred spatial options consultation was held in 2022–23. The emerging draft plan will allocate new strategic sites (e.g. a possible new settlement near Hereford) and update all policies (including addressing the River Wye nutrient neutrality constraints). The council aims to submit the new plan in late 2024. In the meantime, the 2015 policies are considered out-of-date by NPPF criteria. Herefordshire’s housing delivery has also lagged (2022 HDT was 59%, resulting in the presumption applying). This, combined with a lack of 5-year supply in recent years, means the tilted balance is regularly engaged. The risk is therefore high currently, though the forthcoming plan should restore an up-to-date framework by 2025 if delivered on schedule.

name: Cannock Chase LPA
plan_status: Cannock Chase Local Plan (Part 1) adopted June 2014; New Local Plan 2018–2040 submitted Nov 2024
notes_short: Cannock Chase’s 2014 Local Plan (Part 1) is 11 years old. The Council has now submitted a full new Local Plan (covering 2018–2040) in Nov 2024, which is under examination in 2025.
notes: Cannock Chase District’s current adopted Local Plan comprises the Local Plan (Part 1) – Core Strategy adopted in June 2014. A Part 2 site allocations plan was started but never completed. This left Cannock with an aging plan that did not fully allocate sites up to its end date (2028). Recognizing this, the Council prepared a new Local Plan for 2018–2040, which was submitted for examination in November 2024. Hearings are scheduled for May 2025. The emerging plan includes significant housing allocations (e.g. urban extensions south of Cannock and at Rugeley) and addresses cross-boundary needs (Birmingham’s housing shortfall was considered in earlier drafts). Until the new plan is adopted (likely in 2025/26), the 2014 Core Strategy’s policies over 5 years old and an incomplete allocations portfolio mean the NPPF presumption often applies. Indeed, Cannock has been in the tilted balance for residential schemes for several years due to an insufficient 5-year land supply. The imminent new plan should remedy this by providing an updated supply and robust policies on design, climate, etc. Plan risk remains elevated in the short term but is expected to drop once the new plan is in force.

name: Coventry LPA
plan_status: Coventry City Local Plan 2017 adopted Dec 2017; Local Plan Review 2021–2041 published Jan 2025 (Reg19)
notes_short: Coventry’s Local Plan (adopted 2017) is now 8 years old and was subject to a mandatory review in 2022. The Council has prepared a new Local Plan Review (2021–2041), with a publication draft issued in Jan 2025.
notes: Coventry City Council’s current Local Plan was adopted in December 2017, setting an ambitious growth strategy (including a housing target of ~42,400 homes by 2031) and relying on Green Belt releases and neighbouring districts to accommodate overspill. By 2022, Coventry triggered a review of this plan, especially given updated ONS data showed lower population growth than previously projected. The Council has now produced a Coventry Local Plan Review 2021–2041, which was published for Regulation 19 consultation in January 2025. This new draft plan proposes adjusted housing figures (likely reduced from the 2017 plan) and extends policies to 2041. It addresses issues such as delivering the city’s share of the Housing Market Area need while recalibrating for the latest demographic trends. As of early 2025, the plan is not yet adopted, so Coventry is operating with the 2017 plan’s policies. Those are 8 years old, so absent the review, they’d be considered out-of-date – however Coventry took steps to review within 5 years, which may lend some continued weight to the existing policies until the new plan is in place. The city currently has a marginal 5-year land supply and had a Housing Delivery Test result of 82% (2022), meaning a 20% buffer is applied but not the full presumption. With the new plan likely to be adopted by 2026, Coventry’s policy risk is being managed through the review process, though some speculative pressure exists in the interim (particularly on Green Belt sites contested in the new plan).

name: Dudley LPA
plan_status: Black Country Core Strategy (Joint) adopted Feb 2011; New Dudley Local Plan 2023–2041 submitted Feb 2025
notes_short: Dudley’s current plan is the 2011 Black Country Core Strategy, now 14 years old. After the Black Country Plan was aborted in 2022, Dudley pivoted to its own Local Plan, which was submitted in Feb 2025 to meet the deadline for old system plans.
notes: Dudley MBC formerly relied on the Black Country Core Strategy 2011–2026 (jointly adopted in 2011). That plan became very outdated. A joint Black Country Plan review was underway but faced political issues; in 2022, Dudley and others withdrew from the joint process over Green Belt release controversies. Consequently, Dudley developed a standalone Dudley Local Plan 2023–2041, which it submitted for examination in February 2025. This plan identifies sites to meet Dudley’s needs to 2041, focusing development within the urban area and selective Green Belt releases around Kingswinford and Halesowen. The submitted plan will supersede the 2011 Core Strategy upon adoption (expected in 2025/26). Currently, without a modern adopted plan, Dudley has been handling applications under the tilted balance. Housing supply has been short (the borough had <4 years supply in 2022), and the 2022 Housing Delivery Test was only ~50%, leading to the presumption in favor of sustainable development being engaged. The planning risk in Dudley is therefore high until the new plan is adopted. Notably, some major sites (like the failed joint allocation at Green Belt land) remain contentious. The Inspector’s examination of the Dudley Plan will be crucial to restoring an up-to-date policy footing.

name: Wyre Forest LPA
plan_status: Wyre Forest Local Plan Review 2016–2036 adopted April 2022
notes_short: Wyre Forest’s Local Plan Review was adopted in 2022, replacing the previous Core Strategy. It is up-to-date and runs to 2036, so no new plan work is expected until around 2027.
notes: Wyre Forest District Council adopted its Local Plan Review on 26 April 2022. This plan covers the period 2016–2036 and consolidates the formerly separate Core Strategy and Site Allocations documents. Key allocations include the Lea Castle Village (a large mixed-use site) and extensions to Kidderminster. Because the plan is only 3 years old, it is in conformity with current NPPF requirements and provides a 5-year housing land supply (as confirmed in the latest monitoring report). The Council is not currently developing a new plan; they will review by 2027 as per statutory requirements. With an adopted plan in place, Wyre Forest is not subject to the NPPF’s automatic presumption. The 2022 Housing Delivery Test showed ~120% delivery, indicating the plan’s housing strategy is on track. Thus, Wyre Forest’s planning policy has low risk, and focus is on delivery of allocated sites (with infrastructure like the Kidderminster bypass improvements).

name: Central Bedfordshire LPA
plan_status: Central Bedfordshire Local Plan 2015–2035 adopted July 2021; New Local Plan (LURB-style) initiated Jan 2024
notes_short: Central Beds adopted a Local Plan in 2021, which is up-to-date. However, in light of the Levelling Up Act changes and new infrastructure (like East West Rail), the Council decided in Feb 2023 to commence a new Local Plan ahead of schedule.
notes: Central Bedfordshire’s current Local Plan was adopted in July 2021, providing for growth to 2035 (including new villages at Marston Vale and RAF Henlow). This plan is only 4 years old and would ordinarily not be reviewed yet. However, in February 2023 the council resolved that it would be premature to conclude the 5-year review given uncertainty about key infrastructure (East-West Rail) and pending national policy changes. Following the Levelling Up and Regeneration Act 2023, Central Beds in January 2024 decided to prepare a new style Local Plan that integrates new requirements. This effectively launches an update process earlier than required. The current plan remains operative and up-to-date; the council continues to demonstrate a 5-year housing supply (around 5.6 years) and passed the HDT (119% in 2022). Thus, no NPPF default applies. The early start on the next plan (expected adoption by 2028) is a proactive move to address longer-term issues such as the potential new Stewartby Station and adjusted housing targets under the Ox-Cam Arc context. In summary, Central Beds’ plan is up-to-date with low risk now, though an update is underway primarily for future-proofing.

name: Cambridge LPA
plan_status: Cambridge Local Plan 2018 adopted Oct 2018; Greater Cambridge joint Local Plan 2020–2041 in preparation (Reg 18 completed)
notes_short: Cambridge’s 2018 Local Plan is now 7 years old. The City, jointly with South Cambridgeshire, is working on a new Greater Cambridge Local Plan to 2041; a draft preferred plan was consulted on in 2021–22.
notes: Cambridge City Council’s current Local Plan was adopted in October 2018. It was prepared in tandem with South Cambridgeshire’s plan, and together they satisfied housing needs to 2031 (including allocating the new town at Waterbeach and fringe sites around Cambridge). Given rapid growth pressures, work on a joint Greater Cambridge Local Plan 2020–2041 began soon after adoption. Issues & Options consultation occurred in 2020, and a Preferred Options draft (with sites for ~44,400 new homes by 2041) was published in late 2021. However, progress slowed due to concerns over water supply (the “water neutrality” issue in the chalk aquifer) and awaiting government changes. As of 2025, the new joint plan is still in draft, likely to be submitted in 2025. Meanwhile, the 2018 Cambridge Plan is over 5 years old, rendering its policies formally out-of-date. The councils have continued to approve significant developments (e.g. NEC and North East Cambridge area) using a proactive approach, but technically the tilted balance could be applied if a proposal conflicts with the aging plan. Both Cambridge and South Cambs have been able to show >5-year land supply and strong delivery (Cambridge delivered 140% of requirement in 2022), which helps. The risk will persist until the Greater Cambridge Plan is adopted (anticipated ~2026), after which Cambridge will again have an up-to-date framework aligned with longer-term growth and infrastructure (like Cambridge South station and water infrastructure).

name: Fenland LPA
plan_status: Fenland Local Plan 2014 adopted May 2014; New Local Plan 2021–2040 in draft (Reg18 done, paused in 2023)
notes_short: Fenland’s 2014 Local Plan is 11 years old and failing to deliver planned growth. A replacement Local Plan (to 2040) was in progress but paused in late 2023 amid resource issues, leaving a continuing policy vacuum until it resumes.
notes: Fenland District Council’s current Local Plan was adopted in May 2014 and set a high-level growth strategy to 2031 (with broad locations rather than specific allocations). Over the past decade, delivery in Fenland (Wisbech, March, etc.) has lagged targets, and the plan became increasingly out-of-date. The Council began a New Fenland Local Plan 2021–2040 and reached Regulation 18 Draft consultation in 2022. However, as of Q4 2023 the plan process was reportedly “paused” due to staffing and awaiting clarity on national changes. This means Fenland still operates under the 2014 plan. The NPPF presumption applies strongly: the district has consistently been unable to show a 5-year housing land supply (as of April 2023 it was ~2.8 years) and had a Housing Delivery Test result of 45% in 2022, triggering the most severe sanction. Consequently, developers have had success on appeal for unplanned greenfield sites. The lack of an up-to-date plan also complicates securing infrastructure for the planned urban extensions. The council’s risk is high until the new plan is completed. It is expected they will revive the local plan effort in 2024 with a goal of adoption by 2026 if possible, to guide growth in a more managed way. In the interim, Fenland remains in a de facto planning “vacuum” with decisions largely guided by the NPPF.

name: Huntingdonshire LPA
plan_status: Huntingdonshire Local Plan to 2036 adopted May 2019; Full Plan Review started 2022
notes_short: Huntingdonshire’s Local Plan 2036 (adopted 2019) is just over 5 years old. The Council committed to an early Full Plan Review and has already begun that process (the 2040 plan) with Reg 18 consultation, aiming to keep policies fresh.
notes: Huntingdonshire District Council adopted its current Local Plan to 2036 in May 2019. That plan was one of the first to allocate large new settlements (e.g. at Alconbury Weald and St Neots East). Given the plan’s importance in the Oxford-Cambridge Arc context, HDC included a policy to review it by 2024 if needed. Accordingly, the Council commenced a Full Review in 2022. An Issues & Scoping consultation for a new Plan (likely extending to 2040 or beyond) was carried out, and further evidence gathering is underway. As of mid-2025, the 2019 plan is 6 years old, so technically beyond the 5-year mark – however, since a review is actively in train, the council can argue its policies are being kept under scrutiny. The district has maintained above 5-year housing supply (partly due to the Alconbury Weald delivery) and delivered 115% of its housing requirement in 2022, so it hasn’t faced the tilted balance scenario yet. The emerging joint spatial framework for Greater Cambridge and surrounding areas could also influence the new plan. Overall, Huntingdonshire’s current plan is only slightly outdated and is undergoing proactive updating. Risk is comparatively low, mitigated by strong delivery and the active review (though if the new plan were significantly delayed, risk would rise in the late 2020s).

name: Castle Point LPA
plan_status: No up-to-date Local Plan (1998 Plan expired; Draft New Local Plan 2018–2033 found sound but withdrawn June 2022); Council starting fresh plan under new NPPF
notes_short: Castle Point has not had an adopted local plan since 1998. A new Local Plan was developed and even found sound by inspectors in 2022, but the Council withdrew it due to local opposition. The borough now effectively has a policy vacuum, and is likely to begin a new local plan process under the 2023 NPPF regime.
notes: Castle Point Borough’s last adopted Local Plan dates back to November 1998. That plan’s policies largely expired in 2007, leaving only a few saved policies. The Council has made multiple attempts to adopt a new plan. The latest attempt was the New Castle Point Local Plan 2018–2033, which was submitted in 2020 and found sound (with modifications) by the Inspectors in early 2022. However, in June 2022, following local elections and intense opposition to Green Belt releases, the Council voted to withdraw the plan. As a result, Castle Point remains without an NPPF-compliant plan. It faces one of the worst planning situations nationally: no 5-year housing supply, one of the oldest plans in England, and high housing pressure. The government has warned Castle Point (through intervention letters) about its lack of plan. The Council has indicated it will restart plan-making under the new rules (likely aiming to use the more flexible housing targets expected in revised NPPF). In the interim, virtually all housing applications are decided under the NPPF presumption. Recent appeal decisions have allowed large developments on Green Belt (which the withdrawn plan had allocated) due to the absence of an up-to-date plan. Plan risk is extremely high – effectively a planning “vacuum” until a new plan is produced (estimated not before 2026).

name: Chelmsford LPA
plan_status: Chelmsford Local Plan 2013–2036 adopted May 2020; Local Plan Review launched 2022 (Reg18) per early review requirement
notes_short: Chelmsford’s Local Plan was adopted in 2020 and is up-to-date, but it included a commitment to an early review. The Council began a Review in 2022 and is progressing it to extend the plan beyond 2036.
notes: Chelmsford City Council adopted its Chelmsford Local Plan 2013–2036 in May 2020. This plan allocated major growth areas (e.g. Chelmsford Garden Village) to meet needs including some of London’s overspill. As part of the Inspector’s modifications, Policy S1 required an early review to commence by 2022 to address any unmet needs and extend the time horizon. Chelmsford accordingly started a Local Plan Review in late 2022. Issues & Options consultation (branded Local Plan Review 2022) occurred and a Preferred Approach is expected in 2024. The adopted 2020 plan remains sound and in effect – at exactly 5 years old in 2025, it’s on the cusp of requiring an update, but the active review satisfies that. Chelmsford maintains a >5-year housing supply and delivered 164% of its housing requirement in 2022, meaning all NPPF tests are passed. The early review will likely boost housing targets slightly (due to higher household forecasts) and roll the plan forward to 2041. In summary, Chelmsford’s situation is well-managed: the current plan is recent enough to prevent defaulting, and a new plan is already underway to preempt any policy expiry. Plan risk is low.

name: Colchester LPA
plan_status: Colchester Local Plan Section 1 (joint) adopted Feb 2021 and Section 2 adopted July 2022; Local Plan Review underway (Call for Sites done 2023)
notes_short: Colchester completed a two-part Local Plan in 2021–22. It is up-to-date, but an immediate review was triggered to plan beyond 2033 and align with a new Garden Community. The Council started its Local Plan Review in 2023 (e.g. issuing a Call for Sites).
notes: Colchester City Council has a recently adopted Local Plan in two sections: Section 1 (the shared North Essex Authorities strategic plan, adopted Feb 2021) and Section 2 (Colchester-specific allocations, adopted July 2022). This plan guides development to 2033, including the new Tendring/Colchester Borders Garden Community. Upon adoption, Colchester committed to an early review (by 2028 or earlier) to extend the plan if needed. In fact, work on the Local Plan Review began almost immediately – a Call for Sites went out in 2023 and public consultations (“Issues & Options”) have been taking place. The intention is to produce a single new plan covering Colchester to 2040. The current plan, being only ~3–4 years old, is up-to-date and robust. Colchester has a healthy housing land supply (around 6.5 years) and high delivery rates (144% in 2022 HDT). Therefore, it is not defaulting under NPPF. The decision to already start a review is strategic: to secure additional growth beyond 2033, possibly to accommodate any unmet needs from neighbours like Braintree. In sum, Colchester’s plan status is strong, with proactive steps to keep it so. Risk is low.

name: Harlow LPA
notes_short: Harlow’s Local Plan was adopted in December 2020 to guide development until 2033 (including part of the Harlow-Gilston Garden Town). It remains up-to-date. No new plan is being progressed yet, as focus is on delivery of major sites.
notes: Harlow District Council adopted its Local Plan on 10 December 2020. This plan allocates significant growth as part of the Harlow and Gilston Garden Town initiative – including new neighbourhoods on Harlow’s periphery coordinated with East Herts and Epping Forest districts. At 5 years old, the plan is still current and provides a framework for meeting housing needs (around 9,200 homes in Harlow) and employment land. Harlow’s planning efforts are currently centered on implementing these allocations (for example, the Newhall and Gilston sites are progressing). A formal review is not yet initiated, but will be due by 2025 per statutory requirement. However, given the cooperation needed with adjacent districts (Epping’s plan is 2018; East Herts 2018), any review might be aligned regionally. Harlow has maintained a >100% Housing Delivery Test and has a 5-year supply, so NPPF para 11 is not triggered. Environmental constraints (Epping Forest SAC air quality) are monitored but under control through agreed mitigation. In summary, Harlow’s plan situation is stable and low-risk. A new plan is likely beyond the immediate horizon (perhaps around 2027) when extension beyond 2033 will be considered, possibly in a joint West Essex context.

name: Dacorum LPA
plan_status: Dacorum Core Strategy adopted Sept 2013; New Local Plan 2020–2038 submitted Mar 2025; also contributing to SW Herts Joint Strategic Plan 2050
notes_short: Dacorum’s extant plan is a 2013 Core Strategy (plus saved 2004 policies), clearly outdated. The Council has now submitted a new Local Plan (2020–2041) in March 2025, and is working on a South West Herts 2050 strategic plan with neighboring boroughs.
notes: Dacorum Borough’s current adopted development plan consists of the Core Strategy 2006–2031 (adopted September 2013) plus some saved older Local Plan policies for site specifics. These policies are now 10–20 years old. Dacorum has been preparing a new Local Plan 2020–2038 (later extended to 2041) for several years. After delays, the council finally submitted this Local Plan for examination in March 2025. The new plan will accommodate around 20,400 homes (significantly higher annual target than the Core Strategy) and allocate large growth areas around Hemel Hempstead, Berkhamsted and Tring. Concurrently, Dacorum is a participant in the emerging South West Hertfordshire Joint Strategic Plan 2050 – a high-level plan to coordinate growth across Dacorum, Hertsmere, St Albans, Three Rivers, and Watford. That JSP is at early issues stage and likely to inform the next generation of local plans beyond this cycle. In the interim, Dacorum’s planning decisions rely on an out-of-date plan. The borough has been heavily exposed to speculative applications; it has fallen below a 5-year housing land supply (approx. 3.9 years) and Housing Delivery Test was 72% in 2022, resulting in NPPF presumption in favor. Some large greenfield schemes near Hemel have come forward due to this. The submission of the new Local Plan is a critical turning point – if adopted by late 2025, it will restore an up-to-date framework and significantly lower risk. Until then, Dacorum remains vulnerable, albeit now on the path to resolution.

name: Hertsmere LPA
plan_status: Hertsmere Core Strategy adopted Jan 2013; 2021 Draft Local Plan withdrawn Nov 2022; New Plan being restarted (Reg18 expected 2024)
notes_short: Hertsmere’s 2013 Core Strategy is out-of-date. A new Local Plan was in advanced draft by 2021 but was axed after public backlash over Green Belt loss. In April 2024 the council agreed to restart the local plan process from scratch, with a fresh Reg18 in 2024/25.
notes: Hertsmere’s Local Plan Core Strategy was adopted in January 2013, with some policies saved from a 2003 Local Plan. By the mid-2010s it became clear a new plan was needed to meet growth and address London overspill. The Council produced a Draft Local Plan (Reg 19) in 2021 proposing ~12,000 new homes with substantial Green Belt release, but following a wave of opposition and a change in political control, Hertsmere withdrew that draft in November 2022. This left the borough without any emerging plan and relying on a 12-year-old strategy. In April 2024, Hertsmere’s cabinet formally agreed to begin work on a new Local Plan under updated national policy. A new Issues & Options (Reg 18) consultation is expected in late 2024. In the meantime, Hertsmere has almost no readily developable non-Green Belt land left and cannot demonstrate a 5-year housing supply; its 2022 HDT was just 34%, among the lowest in England. Thus, the presumption in favor of development is fully engaged – but paradoxically, many applications are in Green Belt where NPPF provides additional protection. This has resulted in a development stalemate: little housing delivery (hence the low HDT) yet strong resistance to proposals on Green Belt. The plan vacuum keeps risk extremely high. Only once a new plan is adopted (likely ~2026–27) will Hertsmere regain a coherent strategy. Until then, planning is essentially reactive, with the Council heavily defending appeals and using interim measures. Hertsmere is also contributing to the SW Herts 2050 joint strategy, but that is in early stages and won’t directly allocate housing in the short term.

name: St Albans LPA
plan_status: District Local Plan Review 1994 (last plan); Draft Local Plan 2020–2038 submitted Nov 2024 for examination
notes_short: St Albans has the oldest local plan in England (1994). Multiple attempts to replace it failed. The Council finally submitted a new Local Plan in Nov 2024, which is currently under examination in 2025 – potentially ending decades of having no up-to-date plan.
notes: St Albans City & District’s only adopted Local Plan is the District Local Plan Review 1994. This 1994 plan is extremely out-of-date and most policies have been superseded by national policy. St Albans has infamously struggled to adopt a new plan: a 2016 draft failed on Duty to Cooperate in 2020, and previous efforts in the 2000s also faltered. Under threat of government intervention, the Council prepared a new Local Plan 2020–2038, which it submitted in November 2024. This new plan proposes around 15,000 homes and some Green Belt releases to meet both local need and some of Luton’s unmet need. Examination hearings are expected in mid-2025. Until adoption, St Albans remains effectively without an operative plan. The NPPF presumption has been the basis for deciding most significant applications, which has led to piecemeal approvals (e.g. several large sites around Harpenden were allowed on appeal). Housing delivery has been inadequate (the 2022 HDT was 34%, same as Hertsmere, triggering the presumption). The lack of a plan has also hampered infrastructure funding and coordinated development (the district has seen under-provision of affordable housing due to reliance on windfalls). Plan risk is extremely high but – assuming the new plan proceeds to adoption by 2025/26 – St Albans may soon emerge from this long period of planning by appeal. The new plan’s success is critical; if it were to fail examination, direct government intervention is likely. For now, the district sits at the extreme end of NPPF defaulting, with minimal local policy weight in decisions.

name: Cotswold LPA
plan_status: Cotswold District Local Plan 2011–2031 adopted Aug 2018; Partial Update underway ("Green to the Core") and New Local Plan 2026–2041 in early stages
notes_short: Cotswold’s 2018 Local Plan is 7 years old. The District is doing a Partial Update (focused on climate change and refinements) and simultaneously beginning a full new Local Plan to 2041. The current plan remains mostly serviceable but will be superseded around 2025–26.
notes: Cotswold District Council adopted its Local Plan (2011–2031) in August 2018. That plan was broadly compliant with the 2012 NPPF but by 2020 the Council declared a Climate Emergency and decided to partially update the plan to be “Green to the Core”. A Partial Update consultation took place in 2022–23, proposing strengthened environmental policies and minor tweaks to allocations. Concurrently, because the plan’s end date is 2031, the Council has started scoping a full new Local Plan 2026–2041 (the Local Development Scheme indicates preparation ramping up in 2024–25). As of 2025, the adopted plan is slightly out-of-date in terms of housing need (Standard Method suggests a higher annual figure). Cotswold’s housing delivery has been borderline (2022 HDT ~95%) and its 5-year land supply is marginal. Thus, some weight is given to the NPPF presumption on appeal. The Partial Update is intended to extend the life of the 2018 plan until the new plan can be adopted (likely by 2026). Overall, risk is moderate: policies are aging, but the Council’s active updates and generally positive delivery mean the situation is under control. Once the new plan is in place, Cotswold will have an up-to-date framework emphasizing sustainability.

name: Great Yarmouth LPA
plan_status: Great Yarmouth Core Strategy 2013–2030 adopted Dec 2015 (Part 1), modified by Local Plan Part 2 adopted Dec 2021; New Local Plan 2021–2041 submitted Feb 2025
notes_short: Great Yarmouth’s Core Strategy from 2015 is a decade old, though a Part 2 Local Plan in 2021 updated some elements. A comprehensive new Local Plan (2021–2041) has now been submitted (Feb 2025) to replace the older plans.
notes: Great Yarmouth Borough’s current development plan consists of the Core Strategy 2013–2030 adopted in December 2015 and a Part 2 Local Plan adopted in 2021 that allocated additional sites. While the Part 2 (2021) extended the supply, the strategic policies are still from 2015, now 10 years old. The Council has prepared a new Great Yarmouth Local Plan 2021–2041, which it submitted for examination in February 2025. This new plan will integrate the Core Strategy and allocations, addressing needs for an extended period (including regeneration of the waterfront and coastal flood adaptation). Until the new plan is adopted (likely 2026), the borough relies on the mix of 2015 and 2021 plans. Some policies – especially on housing numbers – are considered out-of-date under NPPF because the Core Strategy housing requirement was based on revoked regional targets. However, Great Yarmouth has unique constraints (significant flood-risk areas and economic challenges) that have led to lower delivery historically (the 2022 HDT was ~67%, invoking presumption). The submitted plan proposes ambitious housing growth with mitigation for flood zones. The current risk remains moderate-high: although the Part 2 plan (2021) means many allocations are recent, the overarching strategy is outdated, and the area does not have a full 5-year supply. The situation is set to improve once the new plan is in place with up-to-date policies and allocations through 2041.

name: King’s Lynn and West Norfolk LPA
plan_status: King’s Lynn & West Norfolk Local Plan (Core Strategy 2011 & Site Allocations 2016) – Full Local Plan Review 2016–2036 adopted March 2025
notes_short: King’s Lynn and West Norfolk successfully adopted a comprehensive Local Plan Review in March 2025, consolidating and updating its 2011 Core Strategy and 2016 Site Allocations plan. The district now has an up-to-date plan extending to 2036.
notes: The Borough Council of King’s Lynn and West Norfolk (KLWN) had a Core Strategy (2011) and a Site Allocations Plan (2016). Recognizing the need for a unified update, KLWN undertook a Local Plan Review to 2036. This Local Plan Review was formally adopted in March 2025, replacing both the 2011 and 2016 documents. The new plan provides for approximately 16,100 new homes 2016–2036, including strategic growth at West Winch (south of King’s Lynn) and allocations in rural settlements. It also incorporates updated policies on design, climate change, and town centres. With this adoption, all policies are up-to-date and the borough can demonstrate a healthy 5-year land supply (the plan allocates more than required to ensure flexibility). Prior to adoption, KLWN faced some pressure as the old plan’s end date 2026 loomed, but now that risk has been alleviated. The council will need to consider another review by 2030. For now, the planning framework is sound and NPPF default provisions do not apply. The focus shifts to delivering the allocated sites (including major infrastructure for the West Winch Growth Area) under the certainty of an adopted plan.

name: City of London LPA
plan_status: City of London Local Plan adopted Jan 2015; City Plan 2040 (new Local Plan) submitted Aug 2024
notes_short: The City of London’s current Local Plan dates from 2015. It has been under review (“City Plan 2040”) for several years and was submitted for examination in Aug 2024. In the interim, some policies (especially on offices to resi conversions) default to NPPF due to the plan’s age.
notes: The City of London Corporation’s existing Local Plan was adopted in January 2015. It primarily focused on sustaining the Square Mile as a financial district, with modest housing targets and strict protections for office space. Recognizing changing dynamics (e.g. prior to COVID, then accelerated by it), the Corporation has drafted a new City Plan 2040. This plan was submitted in August 2024 for examination after extensive consultation. The City Plan 2040 introduces more flexible policies for mixed-use developments, encourages sustainable tall buildings and a greening of the City’s public realm, and plans for a post-pandemic balance of office and other uses. Because the 2015 plan is now 10 years old and the new plan is not yet adopted, there have been instances where the City Corporation had to rely on the NPPF (for example, to consider office-to-residential changes or updated development management standards). However, the City has unique circumstances: it consistently over-delivers on office space and has minimal housing obligations (which are easily met on small windfall sites). The lack of a 5-year housing land supply isn’t a concern given the City’s housing target is low (the City delivered ~130 units in 2022, above target). Thus, the main risk from the outdated plan is policy rigidity rather than housing shortfall. The timely adoption of City Plan 2040 (expected in 2025) will restore a fully up-to-date policy set. Risk is moderate and chiefly related to ensuring the City can adapt to modern needs (e.g. integrating urban greening) in the meantime.

name: Hastings LPA
plan_status: Hastings Planning Strategy (Core Strategy) adopted Feb 2014; Sites Local Plan adopted 2015; New Hastings Local Plan 2019–2040 in draft (Reg 18 done, Reg 19 awaited)
notes_short: Hastings’ planning framework is based on a 2014 Strategy and 2015 Allocations plan, both now 8–9 years old. A new Local Plan to 2040 has been in preparation (Reg 18 draft in 2021) but is not yet submitted. In the meantime, Hastings lacks a 5-year housing supply, triggering NPPF presumption for many proposals.
notes: Hastings Borough Council adopted its Planning Strategy in February 2014 and a Development Management Plan (site allocations) in 2015. These set the borough’s development to 2028, with relatively modest housing targets (3,400 homes). By 2019, Hastings began working on a new Local Plan extending to 2040. A Regulation 18 Draft Local Plan was published in early 2021, proposing increased housing (around 4,275 homes by 2040) and new regeneration sites (like expanding the allocation at Bohemia). However, further progress has been slow; as of 2025 the plan has not reached submission. Consequently, Hastings’ 2014/15 plans are now considered out-of-date. The borough consistently undershot housing delivery (2022 HDT was 48%) and cannot demonstrate a 5-year housing supply. This means the tilted balance applies and indeed Hastings has seen several appeal decisions go against it (particularly on the urban fringe where unmet need is cited). Constraints such as limited urban land and environmental designations add complexity. The emerging plan will likely be submitted in 2025, aiming for adoption in 2026 to reset the strategy with realistic yet higher housing targets and strong regeneration focus. Until then, plan risk is high – effectively the NPPF governs development, and the council is vulnerable to developer-led schemes beyond its outdated allocations.

name: Basingstoke and Deane LPA
plan_status: Basingstoke & Deane Local Plan 2011–2029 adopted May 2016; Local Plan Update 2024–2040 under way (Reg18 consulted Oct 2023)
notes_short: Basingstoke’s current Local Plan (adopted 2016) is 9 years old. The council is updating it: an Issues/Options consultation for the new Plan (to cover to 2040) took place in late 2023. The existing plan technically goes to 2029 but will likely be superseded around 2025/26 by the new plan.
notes: Basingstoke and Deane’s Local Plan (2011–2029) was adopted in May 2016. It allocated major greenfield sites around Basingstoke (Manydown, etc.) to meet a requirement of 15,300 homes. The borough committed to an update before 5 years had elapsed. Indeed, a Local Plan Update process began, but progress was delayed by uncertainty over government housing targets. By October 2023, Basingstoke launched a Regulation 18 consultation on options for the new Local Plan 2024–2040. The new plan will address a higher housing need (~17,820 homes) and possibly a new settlement. Meanwhile, the adopted plan—though nearing its end date—still carries weight, but with caution: being 9 years old, the housing policies are subject to NPPF paragraph 11. Basingstoke has a mixed record on delivery: it had a 4.3-year land supply in 2022, so the presumption has been triggered. The council has faced speculative proposals, notably for sites not in the 2016 plan. The emerging plan aims to rectify the supply gap and modernize policies (on environment, infrastructure etc.). Until that is adopted (target 2025), the authority balances using its 2016 policies with acknowledging they’re aging. Risk is moderate-high in the short term, largely due to land supply shortfall, but will reduce once the new plan provides fresh allocations (including likely reserve sites held in the interim).

name: Fareham LPA
notes_short: Fareham adopted a new Local Plan in April 2023, extending its planning horizon to 2037. It’s fully up-to-date and supersedes the previous 2015 plan, so Fareham has a clear framework and no NPPF default issues.
notes: Fareham Borough Council’s Local Plan 2037 was adopted on 30 April 2023. This plan allocates significant housing sites (notably the Welborne Garden Village of 6,000 homes, plus brownfield renewals within the urban area) to meet the borough’s needs up to 2037. It replaced the former 2015 Local Plan. With this recent adoption, Fareham’s policies are all NPPF-compliant and carry full weight. The council has a robust 5-year housing land supply primarily due to Welborne’s anticipated delivery trajectory and steady smaller site supply. Fareham slightly failed the 2022 Housing Delivery Test (at 73%), but because it now has an adopted up-to-date plan with strong supply measures, it is not in a presumption scenario moving forward. The focus is implementing the plan (e.g. delivering infrastructure for Welborne). No plan review is expected until around 2028. Overall, Fareham’s planning context is very low risk after the successful adoption of the 2037 Plan.

name: Gosport LPA
plan_status: Gosport Borough Local Plan 2011–2029 adopted Oct 2015; New Gosport Local Plan 2038 in draft (Reg18 2022, Reg19 expected 2024)
notes_short: Gosport’s last Local Plan (2011–2029) was adopted in 2015 and is now 10 years old. The Borough is preparing a new Local Plan to 2038: a draft Reg 18 was out in 2022, but submission has been delayed. In the meantime, housing land is limited and the plan is dated, so NPPF default likely applies to some decisions.
notes: Gosport Borough Council’s current Local Plan was adopted in October 2015, covering development needs to 2029. As a small urban authority with constrained land (no Green Belt, but limited open sites and significant MoD land), Gosport has struggled to meet housing targets, relying on redevelopment of brownfield sites. The 2015 plan is now beyond 5 years; the Council published a Regulation 18 draft Gosport Borough Local Plan 2038 in 2022 proposing modest additional allocations (e.g. Royal Haslar Hospital site) and an uplifted housing target (~5,500 homes by 2038 vs ~3,060 in old plan). However, further progress has been slow likely due to nutrient neutrality issues affecting the Solent. By 2025, the new plan is not yet at Reg 19. Thus, Gosport’s 2015 plan is considered out-of-date and it cannot demonstrate a 5-year housing supply (recently around 4 years). The NPPF presumption is in effect, but the borough’s lack of available land means few speculative applications come forward (most of Gosport is built-up or constrained by Portsmouth Harbour SPA). The risk lies in under-delivery – Gosport’s 2022 HDT was 47%, triggering presumption. The council continues working on mitigation (nutrient credits, etc.) to unlock housing sites. The forthcoming plan (expected submission in 2024) should help by allocating every feasible site and aligning with sub-regional strategies. Until adoption (likely 2025/26), Gosport’s plan risk is high on paper, but in practice development is slow regardless due to physical constraints. Still, having an updated plan is critical to demonstrate how needs will be met (potentially through partnership with neighbouring areas for any unmet requirement).

name: Hart LPA
plan_status: Hart Local Plan (Strategy & Sites) 2016–2032 adopted April 2020
notes_short: Hart’s Local Plan was adopted in 2020 and is up-to-date. It runs to 2032 with a strategy focused on a new garden village at Shapley Heath (though that project was later paused). Hart is meeting its needs currently and is not yet reviewing the plan.
notes: Hart District Council’s current Local Plan (Strategy and Sites 2016–2032) was adopted in April 2020. It allocates sufficient land for 7,614 new homes, including a new community at Shapley Heath (Murrell Green/Winchfield area) that was intended to be a significant part of the supply. Since adoption, a change in local politics led to Shapley Heath being scaled back (studies halted in 2021), but the plan’s other allocations and a strong pipeline (e.g. Hartland Village redevelopment) keep Hart above its required housing supply. At 5 years old, the plan is just at the threshold of requiring a review; the Council will undertake a formal five-year review in 2025 to decide if an update is needed. So far, Hart has exceeded its housing targets annually (2022 HDT ~150%) and can demonstrate about 8 years of housing land supply. Therefore, the NPPF tilted balance does not apply. No emerging new plan is underway yet. The risk in Hart is low, although there is a known long-term issue of how to accommodate growth beyond 2032 without Shapley Heath – something a future plan update (perhaps late 2020s) will have to address jointly with neighbours if necessary. For now, the adopted plan is performing well and provides certainty for development management.

name: Havant LPA
plan_status: Havant Borough Core Strategy adopted Mar 2011 + Allocations Plan 2014; New Local Plan (“Building a Better Future”) in progress (Reg18 done 2020, examination paused 2022)
notes_short: Havant’s operative plans are a 2011 Core Strategy and 2014 Site Allocations, both long outdated. A new Local Plan 2036 was prepared and submitted in 2021, but the examination was paused over nutrient neutrality issues. The plan process is now resuming under the title “Building a Better Future Plan” with adoption hoped in 2024/25.
notes: Havant Borough Council’s planning policy is presently based on the Core Strategy 2011 and an Allocations Plan adopted in 2014. Clearly, these are out-of-date.
