Havant developed a new Local Plan 2036 and submitted it in 2021, but examination was put on hold due to the Solent nutrient neutrality problem (impacting new housing near sensitive harbors). In Feb 2022 the council withdrew that submission and immediately recommenced work on an updated plan with strengthened environmental measures, now called the “Building a Better Future” Local Plan. By 2023, Havant secured mitigation strategies (a strategic nitrate reduction scheme) and was preparing to re-submit the plan likely in 2024. This stop-start process has left Havant without an up-to-date plan for over a decade. The borough lacks a 5-year housing supply, and its 2022 HDT was 67%, so the NPPF presumption is engaged. However, development in Havant is also constrained by the nutrient issue – until mitigations were in place, the council had imposed a de facto moratorium on new housing permissions. As that is resolving, the new plan will allocate necessary sites (including greenfield urban extensions at Havant and Waterlooville) to meet the Standard Method need (~504 dpa). In the interim, decisions rely on national policy and the aging local policies (which carry limited weight now). Plan risk remains high until the “Better Future” plan is adopted, anticipated in 2025. Thereafter, with an updated plan and nutrient mitigations, Havant’s situation should stabilize. This case underscores how external environmental regulations delayed plan-making, exacerbating the policy vacuum.

name: Canterbury LPA
plan_status: Canterbury District Local Plan 2017–2031 adopted July 2017; New Local Plan 2045 in preparation (Reg18 draft 2022, submission due 2024)
notes_short: Canterbury’s current Local Plan (adopted 2017) is 8 years old. The Council is well advanced in producing a new Local Plan to 2045, which includes ambitious proposals like a new eastern bypass and 16,000+ new homes. Submission is expected in 2024. The aging 2017 plan has somewhat constrained current decisions, but housing delivery remains robust pending the new plan.
notes: Canterbury City’s Local Plan was adopted in July 2017 and planned growth to 2031, including urban extensions at Canterbury, Herne Bay and Sturry. By 2020, work began on a new plan to extend the horizon. A Regulation 18 draft Canterbury District Local Plan 2045 was published in Oct 2022, courting controversy with proposals for a new ring-road and large Greenfield allocations (notably 9,000 homes in a new Canterbury “Garden Community” with a bypass) to accommodate ~16,000 homes. This sparked political change in 2023, but the new administration is continuing the plan process with some revisions. The new plan is due to be submitted in 2024. Meanwhile, the 2017 plan, being over 5 years old, is formally out-of-date. Canterbury has still been delivering strongly (2022 HDT 132%) thanks to sites from that plan coming on stream (e.g. Broad Oak, South Canterbury). However, Canterbury cannot demonstrate a full 5-year supply if using the higher Standard Method targets (which the emerging plan adopts). This means some speculative applications are difficult to resist; indeed, appeals have cited the plan’s age to push unplanned sites at Whitstable (though the Council has generally maintained control by pointing to the imminent new plan). The risk profile is moderate now but will escalate if the new plan is significantly delayed or altered to reduce housing (as that could invite SoS intervention or more appeals). Assuming Canterbury’s new plan proceeds and is adopted by 2025, the district will transition to an up-to-date framework, albeit one that is controversial locally. In summary, current plan risk is managed by active plan-making, but the pressure to get the new strategy in place is high.

name: Dartford LPA
notes_short: Dartford achieved adoption of a new Local Plan in April 2024, replacing its 2011 Core Strategy. The plan runs to 2037, meeting high housing growth demands (largely via Brownfield regeneration in the Thames Gateway). It is fully up-to-date, and the Ebbsfleet Development Corporation applies it for determinations in its area.
notes: Dartford’s previous Core Strategy (2011) was overdue for replacement, and after several drafts, the Dartford Local Plan 2022–2037 was adopted on 4 April 2024. This plan allocates significant development principally on brownfield land in the Dartford urban area and Ebbsfleet Garden City, in line with the Thames Gateway growth area. It sets a housing target of ~790 homes/year and includes large sites like the Dartford Northern Gateway and Ebbsfleet Central. With the plan now adopted, Dartford’s policies are up-to-date and the borough has a comfortable 5-year housing land supply. The adoption also means that Ebbsfleet Development Corporation (which covers part of Dartford) will use this plan as the basis for decisions. There is no need for a new local plan until at least 2029. The risk is extremely low: Dartford has one of the highest housing delivery rates in England (HDT ~240%) due to numerous apartment schemes and major development at Ebbsfleet. The new plan supports continued high delivery while introducing stronger design and environmental policies. NPPF default does not apply in Dartford’s case anymore, and the plan was found sound under the 2021 NPPF, ensuring resilience against upcoming national changes. Focus will be on implementation and working with Ebbsfleet DC. In sum, Dartford’s planning framework is very robust post-2024 plan adoption.

name: Dover LPA
plan_status: Dover District Local Plan 2040 adopted October 2024
notes_short: Dover adopted a brand-new Local Plan (to 2040) in October 2024, replacing its previous Core Strategy (2010) and Land Allocations (2015). It’s up-to-date and in line with latest NPPF, so Dover now has a clear strategy for growth, including a new garden village at Whitfield.
notes: Dover District Council’s new Local Plan 2040 was adopted in October 2024. This comprehensive plan supersedes the older plan documents (Core Strategy 2010 and Allocations 2015). It allocates about 17,000 homes for 2020–2040, focused around Dover town, Whitfield (expanding the existing new community), and strategic allocations at Deal and Aylesham. The plan also deals with coastal change management and infrastructure (e.g. improvements to the A2 to support port traffic). With adoption, Dover’s policies are fully up-to-date and the council can firmly demonstrate a 5-year supply. Historically, Dover had a slight housing delivery shortfall (2022 HDT ~72%, requiring an action plan), but the new plan significantly boosts supply and should improve delivery rates. The council will not need to consider a new plan until the 2030s. Given the plan’s recency, NPPF default provisions do not apply (and indeed the plan was examined under the latest NPPF rules in 2023). Developers now have certainty on where development is acceptable (whereas previously the aging plan led to speculative proposals along the A256 corridor). Plan risk is minimal moving forward; Dover’s focus is on delivery and securing funding for required road upgrades to unlock the larger allocations. In summary, Dover has a low-risk, up-to-date plan environment as of late 2024.

name: Folkestone and Hythe LPA
plan_status: Shepway (Folkestone & Hythe) Core Strategy Review adopted March 2022; Places and Policies Local Plan adopted 2020; up-to-date plan
notes_short: Folkestone & Hythe’s (formerly Shepway) Core Strategy was reviewed and readopted in 2022, alongside a 2020 allocations plan. This gives the district an up-to-date plan including the Otterpool Park Garden Town (10,000 homes) and regeneration in Folkestone. No new plan is needed imminently.
notes: Folkestone & Hythe District Council updated its planning framework with the Core Strategy Review 2020–2037, adopted 30 March 2022. This updated the original 2013 Core Strategy by allocating the Otterpool Park Garden Town (a major new settlement of up to 10,000 homes near the M20) and adjusting other policies (e.g. increased housing target of 738 dpa). It complements the Places and Policies Local Plan adopted in September 2020, which contains detailed site allocations and development management policies for towns and villages. Together, these documents mean the district has a comprehensive up-to-date Local Plan suite. The council can demonstrate a healthy land supply largely thanks to Otterpool Park’s phased delivery (outline permission was granted in 2023). Housing Delivery Test is not an issue (HDT 2022 was 128%). The planning focus is now implementation: Otterpool’s first phases, Folkestone seafront regeneration, and other strategic sites (e.g. at Hythe). With the plan only 1–3 years old, no review is planned until at least 2027. Accordingly, Folkestone & Hythe is not subject to NPPF default rules at present. Plan risk is very low—the district’s growth strategy is settled and has government backing (Otterpool is a Garden Town initiative). Only a substantial failure to progress Otterpool or a radical national policy shift would prompt an earlier plan revisit.

name: Gravesham LPA
plan_status: Gravesham Core Strategy adopted Sept 2014; Site Allocations plan in preparation (Reg 18 Partial Review 2020–21); 5-year Core Strategy review overdue, new Local Plan expected 2024–25
notes_short: Gravesham’s Core Strategy (2014) is 11 years old. A Partial Review was initiated to allocate more housing (due to unmet need from London), but progress stalled. A Regulation 18 consultation on site options happened in 2020–21. The council intends to publish a submission draft in 2024. In absence of allocations beyond 2028, Gravesham lacks a full land supply, making the tilted balance apply currently.
notes: Gravesham Borough’s Core Strategy 2011–2028 was adopted in September 2014. It made provision for ~6,170 homes mainly through regenerating brownfield sites in Gravesend/Northfleet and a strategic allocation at Ebbsfleet (partly overlapping with EDC area). By 2019, it was evident more housing would be needed (Standard Method increased the annual requirement, plus the borough agreed to take some unmet need from the London Plan). The Council embarked on a Partial Review to identify additional sites. A Regulation 18 consultation on growth options and potential Green Belt releases took place in 2020–2021, indicating the need for around 2,000 extra homes and suggesting possible Green Belt allocations around Meopham and Higham. Since then, the process has been slow, partly due to local opposition to Green Belt loss. As of 2025, Gravesham has not submitted a new plan; a pre-submission (Reg 19) draft is anticipated in late 2024. Meanwhile, the 2014 Core Strategy is beyond 5 years and its housing supply (front-loaded brownfield sites) is nearly exhausted. Gravesham cannot demonstrate a 5-year supply (it’s about 3 years), and its 2022 HDT was 50%, triggering NPPF presumption. Several speculative applications for Green Belt sites have come forward as a result. The council has been resisting these pending the plan review, but appeals pose a risk. The situation will persist until the new allocations plan is adopted (likely 2025/26). Plan risk is high in the short term: the policy vacuum after 2028 combined with unmet need puts pressure on unplanned sites. Once the new plan with allocated Green Belt releases is in place, that risk should recede at the cost of sacrificing protected land to meet housing needs.

name: Cherwell LPA
plan_status: Cherwell Local Plan Part 1 adopted July 2015 (with Partial Review for Oxford’s unmet needs adopted Sept 2020); New Cherwell Local Plan 2040 in draft (Reg19 Dec 2024)
notes_short: Cherwell’s Part 1 Local Plan is from 2015 (10 years old), though a Partial Review in 2020 updated it to address Oxford’s unmet housing (4,400 homes at Begbroke/Yarnton). A new Local Plan to 2040 is underway, with a draft published Dec 2024. The current plan remains partially up-to-date due to the 2020 review, but the rest is dated, prompting the full update.
notes: Cherwell District’s Local Plan Part 1 2011–2031 was adopted in July 2015, allocating major sites like NW Bicester Eco-town, Banbury and Bicester urban extensions. In September 2020, the Council adopted a Partial Review (Plan Part 1b) specifically to meet Oxford’s unmet housing need, allocating an additional 4,400 homes in the Kidlington area (north of Oxford). That Partial Review is very recent and those strategic sites are now in early stages of planning. However, aside from that, the main plan remains the 2015 content, which is older. Thus, Cherwell is preparing a new Local Plan 2040 to cover the entire district. A draft Publication Plan was endorsed in Dec 2024, aiming to submit by spring 2025. This plan will extend the strategy to 2040, with further growth in Banbury/Bicester and potentially a new settlement at Arncott. Until the new plan is adopted (likely 2026), Cherwell’s plan is a mix of up-to-date (the 2020 Oxford allocations) and out-of-date (some 2015 era policies). The district has struggled with the 5-year supply recently (4.7 years in 2022), partly due to slower delivery at some strategic sites, which has triggered NPPF presumption for certain proposals. The emerging Plan 2040 addresses this by allocating more deliverable mid-term sites. Meanwhile, Cherwell continues to meet its housing delivery (109% in 2022) and passed the Housing Delivery Test. Plan risk in Cherwell is moderate: while parts of the plan are old, the Partial Review 2020 has injected some fresh supply and the district works closely with Oxon partners. With a new plan in the pipeline, the risk of policy vacuum is being mitigated. Challenges remain if any significant delay occurs, given pressure around Oxford and Bicester for development. The current trajectory though points to a timely update and a managed transition.

name: Guildford LPA
plan_status: Guildford Local Plan: Strategy and Sites 2015–2034 adopted April 2019; Local Plan Part 2 adopted 2021; 5-year plan review due, but no new plan started yet
notes_short: Guildford’s Local Plan Strategy (adopted 2019) is just over 5 years old now. It allocated major Green Belt sites. A Part 2 (development management policies) was adopted in 2021, completing the plan. The Council has not begun a review yet, partly due to unsettled housing target debates. Thus, some policies (like the housing requirement) may be deemed out-of-date post-2024.
notes: Guildford Borough’s Local Plan is split: the Strategy and Sites Plan adopted in April 2019, and the Development Management Policies Plan adopted in July 2021. The 2019 Strategy removed some land from Green Belt and allocated urban extensions (e.g. Blackwell Farm, Gosden Hill) and a new settlement at Wisley Airfield to meet a housing target of 562 dpa (including 4,000 homes for Woking’s unmet need). That plan was controversial but is now well into implementation (planning apps are in for several strategic sites). By April 2024, five years have passed since adoption, triggering the need for a review per NPPF. However, Guildford’s leadership changed in 2023 and is hesitant to plan for further growth beyond 2034 given local opposition and pending reforms. No formal new Local Plan project has been launched yet. The borough technically cannot demonstrate a full 5-year supply if counting Woking’s unmet need (the inspector anticipated early review if Woking couldn’t deliver its portion). Also, Woking’s plan failure (2023) casts uncertainty on Guildford’s commitment. Meanwhile, Guildford’s delivery is strong (HDT 181%) and it has plenty of permitted supply in pipeline. The plan’s policies remain effective, but as the 5-year mark passes without a review underway, developers may begin arguing the housing requirement should default to Standard Method (which is lower for Guildford, ironically ~470 dpa). The risk of tilted balance is low in practice because Guildford can show a 5-year supply under the lower local need. But procedurally, the plan is “aging out.” The Council likely will hold off major review until Woking’s situation and national policy clarify around 2025. So, while currently Guildford’s plan status is technically out-of-date (no review), in reality the plan’s allocations cover the rest of its period. Plan risk is moderate, mostly around legal challenges on unmet need, but day-to-day the plan is guiding development well. A focused review might occur around 2025 to address post-2034 needs if required.

name: Chichester LPA
plan_status: Chichester Local Plan: Key Policies 2014–2029 adopted July 2015; Local Plan Review in progress (was submitted May 2022, then withdrawn due to nutrient neutrality; new Reg19 in May 2024)
notes_short: Chichester’s current Local Plan (adopted 2015) is a decade old and very overdue for replacement. A Review plan was nearly finished in 2022 but got derailed by unresolved nitrate neutrality and transport issues. The council withdrew it and aims to re-publish a new draft in 2024 with revised growth strategy (potentially dropping some contentious greenfield sites). Until a new plan is adopted (likely 2025/26), large parts of Chichester (outside the National Park) have an out-of-date framework, limiting housing delivery and invoking NPPF presumption.
notes: Chichester District’s planning situation is complex due to the South Downs National Park covering the northern half (which has its own plan). For the southern “Chichester Plan Area”, the Local Plan: Key Policies 2014–2029 was adopted in July 2015. It became out-of-date in 2020. The Council prepared a Local Plan Review aiming for adoption by 2020, but encountered delays primarily from the need to mitigate nitrate pollution affecting Chichester and Langstone Harbours (similar to Havant’s issue) and highways constraints on the A27 at Chichester. A Submission draft was actually agreed and submitted in May 2022, but the examination could not progress as Natural England maintained an objection on nutrient grounds and infrastructure agreements were incomplete. Chichester ultimately withdrew the plan in May 2023 to avoid it being found unsound. They are now updating evidence and intend to publish a revised Regulation 19 draft by May 2024. This new draft may reduce housing numbers slightly (previously ~12,350 homes to 2037) and adjust allocations (possibly scaling back development in areas affected by nutrient neutrality until a solution is at hand). In the interim, Chichester’s housing supply has fallen under 5 years and the 2022 HDT was 34%, so the tilted balance applies strongly. However, because of the environmental constraints, the council has had a moratorium on many housing permissions, so not much development can exploit the presumption. The planning vacuum is problematic: no up-to-date plan means speculative proposals, but many are blocked by nutrient concerns, creating a stalemate. Plan risk is high; central government has closely watched Chichester’s plan progress. If the new plan is further delayed, intervention is possible. Adoption by 2025/26 is critical to allocate deliverable sites with nutrient mitigation in place. Until then, Chichester remains in limbo with severely constrained housing delivery. The hope is that a resolution on nutrient mitigation (potentially via regional water treatment upgrades or nutrient credit schemes) will align with the new plan adoption, unlocking development and alleviating the current risk.

name: Crawley LPA
notes_short: Crawley’s new Local Plan to 2037 was adopted in Oct 2024, replacing the 2015 plan. It addresses very high housing need (capped by land constraints) through urban intensification and continued reliance on Horsham/Mid Sussex for overspill. It is up-to-date and in line with the latest NPPF.
notes: Crawley Borough Council adopted the Crawley 2037 Local Plan in October 2024. This plan update was delayed due to the pandemic and uncertainties, but now supersedes the Crawley 2015 Local Plan. Crawley’s situation is unique: it has one of the highest housing needs relative to its area, but is constrained by tight boundaries and the Gatwick Airport noise zone, meaning it cannot meet all its need within. The 2037 Plan provides capacity for ~5,355 homes (375 dpa) largely via town centre regeneration and urban sites (e.g. Telford Place), against a need of ~752 dpa – the shortfall continues to be exported under cooperation to Horsham and Mid Sussex (a long-standing arrangement). The new plan was found sound with that unmet need approach and includes policies to maximize affordable housing and employment growth (Manor Royal is protected for business). Being brand new, the plan’s policies carry full weight and Crawley can maintain a 5-year supply on its reduced local target (it also benefits from the NPPF footnote that caps its requirement due to constraints). The council will likely not review the plan until around 2029 unless circumstances drastically change (e.g. if Gatwick’s expansion triggers a need to update policies). Plan risk is very low for Crawley now: although housing delivery will always be behind the raw need, the agreed redistribution through the West Sussex/Northern West Sussex housing market area means no presumption is triggered. The main challenge will be ensuring neighbouring plans (Horsham’s, Mid Sussex’s) also progress to continue accommodating Crawley’s unmet need – but Crawley’s own plan is sound and up-to-date.

name: Horsham LPA
plan_status: Horsham District Planning Framework (HDPF) adopted Nov 2015; Horsham Local Plan Review 2019–2039 in progress (Reg19 drafted, decision delayed post-2023 elections)
notes_short: Horsham’s current plan (HDPF 2015) is 10 years old. A new Local Plan to 2039 was nearly ready for submission in 2021, but political changes stalled it. In 2023, a new council administration is re-evaluating spatial options, especially a controversial new town at Buck Barn. The delay keeps Horsham without an updated plan – which is problematic given it also takes on unmet need from Crawley. The council still has a solid housing supply pipeline from the 2015 plan (e.g. North of Horsham development), but as time goes on, the lack of a new plan could undermine its supply and trigger more appeals.
notes: Horsham District’s Planning Framework (HDPF) was adopted in November 2015, setting out development to 2031 including major allocations like 2,500 homes north of Horsham (now under construction). Horsham also agreed to take 150 dpa of Crawley’s unmet need in that plan. A Local Plan Review to 2038/39 began in 2018 with high growth proposals (including several new settlement options). A Regulation 19 draft was prepared in 2020 proposing ~1,200 dpa (including a 3,500-home new garden village at Buck Barn), but its final approval was postponed pending updated government policy. After May 2023 local elections, a new administration in Horsham indicated it might drop or change the new settlement plans. As of 2025, the plan is still not submitted and is being reworked – likely with a new Reg 19 in 2024 that could redistribute growth. Because of this, the 2015 HDPF remains the operative plan and is past its 5-year mark. Horsham has continued to build robustly (2022 HDT 173%) thanks to large sites in the pipeline, and currently can show about 6 years of supply. However, without a new plan, by late 2020s that supply will diminish. Already, speculative proposals (e.g. for more expansion at Southwater) have come forward arguing the plan is aging. The council has managed to fend these off so far by pointing to advanced plan progress and current supply, but further delay heightens risk. If the new plan isn’t submitted by mid-2025, the South East regional examiner could intervene, as Horsham is one of the few districts in Sussex without a plan at least submitted. Once Horsham does adopt a new plan (expected around 2025/26 if political consensus is reached), it will meet a higher share of its own need plus maintain support for Crawley’s unmet needs – critical for the Gatwick Diamond area. In sum, plan risk is moderate now (buffered by ongoing large site build-out) but will increase steadily until the new plan is in place.

name: Cornwall LPA
plan_status: Cornwall Local Plan: Strategic Policies 2010–2030 adopted Nov 2016; No full review yet (partial updates via Site Allocations DPDs 2019); New Local Plan in early scoping stage 2023
notes_short: Cornwall’s unitary Local Plan was adopted in 2016 and has not been comprehensively reviewed since. Some site allocations plans were done in 2019 for main towns. The Council signalled intent to update the Local Plan (to align with the 2050 Cornwall vision) but formal work is still in early stages. At 9 years old, the plan’s housing targets are based on revoked regional strategies and due for replacement. However, housing delivery in Cornwall has exceeded targets (HDT ~144%), and large planning permissions (especially around eco-communities like West Carclaze) are in place, somewhat buffering the risk from the dated plan in the short term.
notes: Cornwall Council’s Local Plan: Strategic Policies was adopted in November 2016, shortly after Cornwall became a unitary. It set a countywide housing target of 52,500 homes 2010-2030, distributed to town network areas, with an emphasis on eco-communities (e.g. West Carclaze near St Austell) and urban extensions to towns like Truro and Bodmin. Detailed site allocations for key towns were covered by a separate Site Allocations DPD adopted in 2019. Since then, Cornwall has pivoted to climate emergency and “devolution deal” priorities. The Local Plan is now aging – by 2025 it’s 9 years since adoption. The Council has expressed ambition for a new planning strategy to 2050 (aligned with carbon neutral goals and possibly reducing housing growth to more locally acceptable levels), but formal review has been slow to start, likely awaiting clarity on national planning reforms. In practice, Cornwall’s expansive geography and numerous extant planning consents (with around 30k permissions in the pipeline) mean it continues to have above 5-year supply and strong delivery (HDT 2022 was 144%). Thus, although the plan is technically out-of-date after 5 years, the council has generally not faced the tilted balance except in some appeal cases where specific policies (like those on infill development) were considered inconsistent with NPPF. The risk of speculative development is moderated by the fact that most towns already have allocated urban extensions and the Council can cite its large existing supply. Nonetheless, some policy areas – e.g. affordable housing thresholds, climate policies – would benefit from an update. The Council is likely to commence a full Local Plan update in 2024 with a view to adoption around 2026/27. For now, plan risk is moderate: not immediately dire due to good supply metrics, but the lack of up-to-date strategic vision could become an issue if delivery stalls or if the unitary pursues major policy shifts (like restricting second homes) that require new plan policies. Cornwall also must coordinate with the emerging Devon & Cornwall connectivity strategy (e.g. spaceport, offshore wind), which a new plan will eventually need to incorporate.

name: Cheltenham LPA
plan_status: Gloucester-Cheltenham-Tewkesbury Joint Core Strategy (JCS) adopted Dec 2017; Cheltenham Borough Local Plan (site allocations) adopted July 2020; JCS Review underway (Reg18 2023)
notes_short: Cheltenham’s strategic plan is the 2017 Joint Core Strategy, which is being reviewed jointly with Gloucester and Tewkesbury (Reg 18 Issues & Options consulted Oct 2023). Cheltenham also adopted a local-level plan in 2020. The combined plan is just beyond 5 years old, and big strategic allocations (e.g. NW Cheltenham) are only now proceeding. With the review in motion, Cheltenham’s policies still carry weight, but the council is keen to extend the plan to 2041 to accommodate things like the Cyber Central Garden Community. Housing delivery is on track (HDT ~150%), so NPPF presumption has not been triggered, but getting the JCS Review done by 2025 is important to keep a valid framework.
notes: Cheltenham’s planning policy is inextricably linked with Gloucester and Tewkesbury through the Joint Core Strategy (JCS) adopted in December 2017. The JCS provides strategic allocations, including the large urban extensions at North West Cheltenham (~4,285 homes) and West Cheltenham (Cyber Park, ~1,100 homes). Cheltenham then adopted its own Cheltenham Plan in July 2020 to allocate smaller sites and update development management policies. This means Cheltenham has a full plan suite – albeit composed of two parts. The JCS is now 8 years old and was due a review in 2022 per its Inspector’s recommendation. That review is underway: Issues & Options for the JCS Review 2041 went out in Oct 2023, looking at additional growth locations (including possibly further expansion around Cheltenham and a new settlement at Flowerdown). So far, the existing JCS has not hindered development – Cheltenham has maintained over a 6-year housing land supply, buoyed by progress on the big allocations and lots of windfall flats in the town. The 2022 HDT was 151%. So while technically the plan is >5 years, its policies are largely still relevant (especially since the 2020 local plan refreshed many DM policies). Nonetheless, to avoid any future shortfall (given that NW Cheltenham is only just starting and might not deliver at anticipated rates), the timely adoption of the JCS Review (target ~2025/26) is needed. Potential risk factors include if Tewkesbury or Gloucester hit complications (e.g. flood constraints in Gloucester may force more growth to Cheltenham’s area). But as of now, all three councils are committed to the joint review. The plan risk for Cheltenham is thus low-moderate: current policies suffice, but by 2025 if the review hasn’t advanced, developers might start pushing unallocated sites. Assuming the review stays on schedule, Cheltenham will get an updated framework through 2041 with increased allocations (likely including an expanded Cyber Central Garden Village). Until then, the existing JCS and Cheltenham Plan are managing development adequately and NPPF default has not been a major issue.

name: Forest of Dean LPA
plan_status: Forest of Dean Core Strategy 2012 & Allocations Plan 2018; New FoD Local Plan 2021–2041 under development (Preferred Option consulted 2022, process delayed due to nutrient neutrality)
notes_short: Forest of Dean’s plan comprises an old Core Strategy (2012) and a 2018 Allocations Plan. A new Local Plan 2041 has been in the works since 2019; a Preferred Option focusing growth in a new town at Sharpness was consulted on in 2022 but then paused, partly due to the nutrient neutrality embargo affecting the River Wye catchment. The plan process has recently restarted. Meanwhile, much of FoD’s housing delivery is stalled by the river pollution issue, leaving the district unable to meet targets. Until the plan is done and mitigation in place, the area is effectively under a development moratorium – the NPPF presumption doesn’t help if permissions can’t be granted. This is a high-risk situation that hinges on environmental resolutions and completing the new plan by 2025/26.
notes: Forest of Dean District currently relies on a Core Strategy (2012) and an Allocations Plan (2018). These provided for growth up to 2026 across the district’s towns (Cinderford, Coleford, Lydney) and some larger villages. However, since 2019 the LPA has been preparing a new Local Plan 2021–2041 to set a fresh strategy. A controversial Preferred Option emerged that heavily favored a new garden village at Sharpness (on FoD’s extreme south-eastern tip) to accommodate a big chunk of housing, rather than expanding the existing towns. This met resistance in local consultations in 2022. Complicating matters, a Natural England ruling in 2021 found the River Wye SAC is in poor condition, halting virtually all new housing in northern FoD (Cinderford area) until nutrient neutrality can be achieved. Thus, the council paused the plan process to gather more evidence and work on mitigation strategies. As of late 2023, they signalled intent to resume the Local Plan, likely adjusting the spatial distribution (possibly reducing reliance on Sharpness and focusing on Lydney which is outside the Wye catchment). The timeline now likely sees a new Reg 19 in 2024 and submission by 2025. In the interim, FoD’s housing supply is critically impacted: the HDT 2022 was 0% (housing delivery basically ceased in the affected catchment), and the district cannot show a 5-year supply. Yet the usual NPPF presumption is moot because the council simply cannot lawfully grant consents adding to the Wye’s nutrient load without mitigation. So the risk here is not typical speculative-building risk but rather a stagnation risk. The new plan is crucial as it will designate nutrient mitigation areas, update targets (which may need to be lower unless catchment solutions free up capacity), and allocate deliverable sites (likely more at Lydney which drains to the Severn estuary instead). Until then, FoD remains in limbo. It’s a high-risk scenario from a plan-making perspective because without resolution the council can’t meet legal requirements and could face designation or appeals citing non-determination. The bright spot is that being a two-plan district, any overspill from Gloucester/Cheltenham will probably bypass FoD due to these issues. But internally, unlocking sustainable development relies on getting the new plan and nutrient strategy in place. 2024 will be a decisive year. Overall, the current plan is outdated and largely ineffective under present constraints – risk is high until the new plan and environmental measures restore a functional planning regime.

name: Gloucester LPA
plan_status: Gloucester-Cheltenham-Tewkesbury Joint Core Strategy adopted Dec 2017; Gloucester City Plan (allocations) adopted Dec 2022; JCS Review in progress (Reg18 consulted 2023)
notes_short: Gloucester’s strategic plan is the 2017 JCS (see Cheltenham for context), and it recently adopted its own City Plan in 2022 to allocate sites to 2031. With that, Gloucester’s development plan is up-to-date. However, Gloucester faces severe housing land constraints (limited expansion room and high flood risk), so the JCS Review will be crucial to identify how growth post-2031 is handled (likely more reliance on Cheltenham/Tewkesbury). In the meantime, Gloucester is delivering regeneration schemes (e.g. King’s Quarter) and meeting targets – there’s no presumption issue. The JCS Review will ensure a longer-term strategy (possibly up to 2041) is agreed by 2025.
notes: Gloucester City shares the 2017 Joint Core Strategy (JCS) with Cheltenham and Tewkesbury, which provided the overarching strategy including urban extensions at Innsworth and Churchdown (in Tewkesbury borough) to help meet Gloucester’s needs. The city itself is tightly bounded, with Green Belt to north and east and Severn floodplain to west. In December 2022, Gloucester adopted its City Plan 2011-2031, allocating remaining sites within the city (mostly brownfield regenerations and some small greenfield on fringes). This completed the local plan coverage and enabled the council to demonstrate a healthy land supply (over 7 years). The city’s Housing Delivery Test for 2022 was 141%, reflecting strong output from sites like Bakers Quay and Kingsway. With the City Plan, Gloucester’s local policies are up-to-date. The focus now shifts to the JCS Review, which is underway for post-2031. Given Gloucester’s constraints, the review’s big question is how much growth can be accommodated within or adjacent to the city. The 2023 Issues consultation raised the possibility of a major new settlement at Stoke Orchard (Tewkesbury) partly to serve Gloucester’s longer term growth. Gloucester City will rely on the partnership to ensure its needs are met to 2041, as its own capacity is limited (most suitable sites are already used or allocated). But since that cooperation is active and formalized in the JCS, plan risk is low. There’s no immediate risk of speculative sprawl because outside Gloucester’s boundary is protected Green Belt or in Tewkesbury’s jurisdiction (where JCS policies still hold). So Gloucester’s planning context is stable and relatively low-risk. The only potential issue is if the JCS Review significantly faltered, Gloucester could eventually face a supply shortfall late in the 2020s. However, progress so far indicates adoption of the review by 2025. In summary, Gloucester has an up-to-date local plan (2022) and is engaged in an on-track joint strategic review, making its situation secure under the NPPF at present.

name: Dartmoor National Park LPA
notes_short: Dartmoor National Park Authority adopted a new Local Plan in Dec 2021, which is up-to-date and runs to 2036. It focuses on small-scale, locally-led development compatible with National Park purposes. There is no sign of any need to update it yet, as it meets current NPPF requirements and development pressure is low/moderate.
notes: The Dartmoor National Park Authority (DNPA) adopted the Dartmoor Local Plan 2018–2036 on 3 December 2021. This plan covers the entire National Park and sets out policies balancing conservation with meeting local needs (primarily affordable housing for local communities and limited employment space). It replaced the previous 2004/2011 plans. Being only 3-4 years old, the plan is very much up-to-date. It identifies small-scale housing sites in larger villages (e.g. Ashburton, Buckfastleigh) and includes a rural exception housing approach for local occupancy. The DNPA has a small housing requirement (around 65 homes/year) which is being met through this plan. Delivery is on track (the Authority delivered 103% of its modest housing target in 2022) and a 5-year supply exists primarily due to windfall and allocated village sites. The Dartmoor plan also includes robust environmental protections aligning with the 2021 NPPF (e.g. strong controls on major development per para 176). As such, the plan faces no NPPF default issues. The National Park is not subject to mandated 5-year reviews in the same way as high-growth councils, but DNPA will likely still review its policies by 2026 to ensure compliance with any new national park management plan objectives. For now, plan risk is very low – the policy framework is current and suited to the NP context, and development pressure is relatively minimal and catered for. The only foreseeable change might come if government were to introduce new requirements (e.g. biodiversity net gain) that the DNPA might incorporate via a light touch update, but nothing that undermines the overall plan. In summary, Dartmoor’s Local Plan is sound, up-to-date, and not in need of replacement before the late 2020s.

name: Exmoor National Park LPA
plan_status: Exmoor National Park Local Plan 2011–2031 adopted July 2017
notes_short: Exmoor National Park’s Local Plan was adopted in 2017. It remains largely fit for purpose, focusing on local needs housing and conservation, but at 8 years old it is approaching the time for a review. The National Park Authority has not signalled a new plan yet; presumably an update will be undertaken around 2025-26. Given very low development pressure and a unique policy environment (e.g. nearly all housing is rural exceptions for local occupancy), the plan’s age has not led to any significant issues under the NPPF. It still effectively guides decisions, and Exmoor easily meets its minimal housing targets via windfalls and conversions.
notes: The Exmoor National Park Authority (ENPA) adopted its current Local Plan in July 2017, covering 2011–2031. Like other national parks, its plan emphasizes environmental protection and only permits new development in exceptional or locally justified circumstances. For housing, Exmoor’s plan set a low annual target (~20 dwellings/year) all to be delivered as local needs affordable housing or succession farm dwellings, etc. This model has worked within the Park: most housing comes from barn conversions or small exception sites, and the NPA consistently meets this need. Because of the small scale and the alignment with NPPF’s approach to National Parks, the plan’s policies remain effective 8 years on. There have been no significant development proposals that test the limits of the plan (no major housing schemes or industry that would invoke NPPF para 177 because none would be allowed or proposed). The plan likely requires a review in the next few years to roll forward beyond 2031 and incorporate updated climate change mitigations, but the ENPA has limited resources so may coordinate this with the update of the Park Management Plan timeline. Until then, the risk posed by an “outdated” plan is negligible – Exmoor’s protected status means general presumption in favor of development doesn’t apply strongly (footnote 60 of NPPF), and the park hasn’t seen any appeals exploiting the plan’s age. Essentially, development management carries on with the 2017 policies unchallenged. So, while technically beyond 5 years, Exmoor’s plan can be considered effectively up-to-date in practice. Plan risk is extremely low; updates will be driven more by new environmental standards (like stronger climate adaptation measures for heritage buildings) rather than by any urgent land supply or development pressure issue.

name: Ebbsfleet Development Corporation LPA
plan_status: No independent Local Plan; uses Dartford’s Local Plan (adopted 2024) and Gravesham’s Local Plan (2014, under review); guided by 2017 Ebbsfleet Implementation Framework (non-statutory)
notes_short: Ebbsfleet DC doesn’t have its own adopted Local Plan. Planning decisions default to the existing borough plans: Dartford’s new Local Plan 2024 covers the western part of Ebbsfleet, while Gravesham’s old 2014 Core Strategy (outdated, new plan due 2025) covers the eastern part. The EDC uses a 2017 masterplan (Implementation Framework) as informal guidance. Until Gravesham’s plan is updated, there is a policy vacuum for Ebbsfleet’s eastern area. Dartford’s side is up-to-date. This split framework adds complexity but the situation will improve once Gravesham’s emerging Local Plan is adopted, bringing the whole Garden City under current policies.
notes: Ebbsfleet Development Corporation was established to oversee a cross-boundary Garden City spanning parts of Dartford and Gravesham. It relies on Dartford’s Local Plan (adopted 2024) and Gravesham’s Local Plan Core Strategy (2014) for statutory policy. Dartford’s plan (which specifically allocates Ebbsfleet Central etc.) is up-to-date and Ebbsfleet DC applies it in determining applications on Dartford side. In contrast, Gravesham’s 2014 plan is over 5 years old and didn’t foresee the scale of Ebbsfleet development; Gravesham is working on a new plan (Reg 19 due 2024) to rectify this. In the interim, Ebbsfleet DC uses the non-statutory Ebbsfleet Implementation Framework 2017 as a coordinated masterplan (covering design, infrastructure phasing) but this has no legal weight in lieu of a local plan. As a result, for big sites like Ebbsfleet Central and Eastern Quarry, the EDC has had to negotiate within the patchwork of one up-to-date plan (Dartford) and one outdated plan (Gravesham). This hasn’t stopped progress – thousands of homes are underway – but it poses some planning risk (e.g. challenge potential if decisions in Gravesham area rely on older policies). The risk is being managed: EDC works closely with Gravesham, and major permissions (such as for eastern Ebbsfleet residential schemes) include comprehensive conditions aligning with the masterplan. By 2025, once Gravesham’s new Local Plan is adopted, Ebbsfleet will fully benefit from current local policy across all areas. In summary, Ebbsfleet’s planning status is atypical: there is effectively a temporary policy vacuum on roughly half the area, mitigated by the EDC’s framework and Dartford’s modern plan. The resolution is in sight via Gravesham’s plan review. The situation highlights the need for unified planning but so far has not halted Ebbsfleet’s development momentum. Plan risk for EDC is moderate now and expected to be low once the remaining borough plan catches up.

name: Cumberland LPA
plan_status: New unitary (est. Apr 2023) – inherits Local Plans of former Allerdale (2014/18), Carlisle (2016) and Copeland (just adopted 2024). Work has begun on a new Cumberland Local Plan to unify these by ~2027
notes_short: Cumberland Council formed in 2023, replacing three districts. It currently operates under three different inherited Local Plans: Copeland’s Plan (2021–2038) adopted in 2024 (up-to-date), Carlisle’s Local Plan 2015–2030 (adopted 2016, aging), and Allerdale’s Local Plan (Part 1 adopted 2014, Part 2 in 2018). The new Council has started preparing a single Cumberland Local Plan to cover the whole area. Until that is adopted (likely 2026/27), decisions rely on the mix of old plans: Copeland area is well covered by a fresh plan, Carlisle and Allerdale areas have older plans. That could lead to inconsistencies or default NPPF tests in some cases, but the council will manage via using the most up-to-date evidence and quickly progressing the unified plan.
notes: Cumberland Council is a new unitary combining the former districts of Carlisle, Allerdale, and Copeland (excluding the part in Lake District NP). It therefore inherited multiple local plans. Copeland’s new Local Plan 2021–2038 was adopted by Cumberland Council in April 2024, giving up-to-date coverage for the Whitehaven/Copeland area. Carlisle’s City Local Plan (2015–2030) adopted in 2016 now falls under Cumberland – it’s somewhat dated but largely delivered (Carlisle met its targets with the garden village at St Cuthbert’s well underway). Allerdale had a 2014 Core Strategy and a 2018 Site Allocations Plan; those are around 5-9 years old, still generally effective for towns like Workington/Maryport, but due for review. Cumberland Council’s priority is to create one new Cumberland Local Plan to cover the whole authority. According to its March 2024 Local Development Scheme, work commenced in 2023 and a Reg18 Issues consultation is expected in 2024. This new plan will run likely to 2040 and reconcile the varying policies and growth targets of its predecessor areas (e.g. align housing distribution across the former district boundaries). In the interim, planning decisions refer to the saved policies of the existing plans: in practice, the Copeland area has up-to-date policies (so no issues there), while Carlisle/Allerdale areas must lean on somewhat older policies. Where those are silent or out-of-date, Cumberland can use NPPF (e.g. to apply the Standard Method for any five-year supply calc, which in Carlisle’s case actually lowers the requirement since the 2016 plan had higher housing targets). The council is also applying recent evidence uniformly (for example, a new county-wide housing need study) to inform decisions across the patch. This patchwork isn’t ideal but is manageable in the short term. The biggest risk would be any major proposal that spans the old boundaries – but those are unlikely. The presumption could apply in parts of Carlisle/Allerdale if land supply dips, but both had relatively healthy supplies at last count (Carlisle ~6 years, Allerdale ~5.5). The prompt progression of the Cumberland Local Plan should mitigate long-term risk. Overall, while Cumberland’s planning framework is currently fragmented, the situation is under control: one-third of the area is covered by a brand-new plan (Copeland), and no area is completely lacking a plan. The key is unifying and updating them in the next few years, which is underway. Thus plan risk is moderate during this transition, expected to fall to low once the new plan is adopted.

name: Cotswold LPA
plan_status: Cotswold District Local Plan 2011–2031 adopted Aug 2018; Partial Update underway ("Green to the Core") and New Local Plan 2026–2041 in early stages
notes_short: Cotswold’s 2018 Local Plan is 7 years old. The District is doing a Partial Update (focused on climate change and refinements) and simultaneously beginning a full new Local Plan to 2041. The current plan remains mostly serviceable but will be superseded around 2025–26.
notes: Cotswold District Council adopted its Local Plan (2011–2031) in August 2018. That plan was broadly compliant with the 2012 NPPF but by 2020 the Council declared a Climate Emergency and decided to partially update the plan to be *Green to the Core*. A Partial Update consultation took place in 2022–23, proposing strengthened environmental policies and minor tweaks to allocations. Concurrently, because the plan’s end date is 2031, the Council has started scoping a full new Local Plan 2026–2041 (the Local Development Scheme indicates preparation ramping up in 2024–25). As of 2025, the adopted plan is slightly out-of-date in terms of housing need (Standard Method suggests a higher annual figure). Cotswold’s housing delivery has been borderline (2022 HDT ~95%) and its 5-year land supply is marginal. Thus, some weight is given to the NPPF presumption on appeal. The Partial Update is intended to extend the life of the 2018 plan until the new plan can be adopted (likely by 2026). Overall, risk is moderate: policies are aging, but the Council’s active updates and generally positive delivery mean the situation is under control. Once the new plan is in place, Cotswold will have an up-to-date framework emphasizing sustainability.
